pros: Working at Cornell University offers numerous advantages and opportunities for professionals. Here are some of the key benefits of being a part of the Cornell community: Academic Excellence: Cornell University is renowned for its commitment to academic excellence and is consistently ranked among the top universities globally. As a professional at Cornell, you will have the opportunity to work alongside world-class faculty and researchers, contributing to cutting-edge advancements in your field. Collaborative Environment: Cornell fosters a collaborative and interdisciplinary environment, encouraging professionals from various disciplines to collaborate and exchange ideas. This provides a rich and stimulating work environment, promoting innovation and creativity. Professional Development: Cornell University is dedicated to supporting the professional growth and development of its employees. The university offers a range of training programs, workshops, and resources to enhance your skills and knowledge. Additionally, Cornell's extensive network and connections can provide opportunities for networking, mentorship, and career advancement. Diversity and Inclusion: Cornell values diversity and inclusivity and strives to create a welcoming and supportive environment for all. By working at Cornell, you will be part of a community that celebrates diverse perspectives, experiences, and backgrounds, fostering a culture of inclusiveness and mutual respect. State-of-the-Art Facilities and Resources: As an employee of Cornell, you will have access to state-of-the-art facilities, cutting-edge research equipment, libraries, and extensive resources that support your work and research endeavors. These resources enable you to excel in your field and make significant contributions to your area of expertise. Work-Life Balance: Cornell University recognizes the importance of maintaining a healthy work-life balance. The university offers a range of benefits and support services to help employees achieve this balance, including flexible work arrangements, comprehensive healthcare options, wellness programs, and various recreational and cultural activities. Engaged and Vibrant Community: Cornell has a vibrant community of faculty, staff, and students, offering ample opportunities for engagement and involvement. From attending seminars, conferences, and cultural events to participating in clubs and organizations, you will have the chance to connect with like-minded individuals, expand your network, and contribute to the Cornell community. These are just a few of the many advantages of working at Cornell University. It is a place where you can grow professionally, collaborate with top scholars, and make a meaningful impact in your field of expertise.
cons: While working at Cornell University offers many benefits, it's important to consider some potential challenges or drawbacks as well. Here are a few cons that some individuals may experience while working at Cornell: High Cost of Living: Cornell University is located in Ithaca, New York, which has a relatively high cost of living compared to other areas. Housing, transportation, and everyday expenses can be expensive, which may impact your overall financial situation. Workload and Stress: Like many academic institutions, Cornell University is known for its rigorous academic environment and high expectations. Depending on your role and department, you may experience heavy workloads, tight deadlines, and demanding responsibilities. This can lead to increased stress levels and work-life imbalance. Limited Career Advancement Opportunities: Due to the university's large size and competitive nature, career advancement opportunities may be limited in certain fields or departments. Advancing to higher positions or securing tenure can be highly competitive and require significant effort and dedication. Harsh Winters: Ithaca experiences cold and snowy winters, which can be challenging for some individuals, particularly if they are not accustomed to such weather conditions. Winter storms and icy conditions may affect commuting and outdoor activities. Limited Diversity in Surrounding Area: While Cornell University promotes diversity and inclusivity, the surrounding area may have limited diversity compared to larger metropolitan areas. This can impact social and cultural experiences for individuals seeking a more diverse community. Funding Challenges: Like many educational institutions, funding for research and projects can be competitive and limited. Securing external grants or funding may require significant time and effort, which can be a challenge for researchers and faculty members. Limited Networking Opportunities Outside the University: While Cornell University provides a robust network within the academic community, building connections outside the university or in industries unrelated to academia may require additional effort. The university's focus on research and academia may limit exposure to other professional networks. It's important to note that these cons may vary depending on individual circumstances, roles, and departments within Cornell University. It's advisable to thoroughly research and consider these factors when making decisions about employment at the university.

pros:
Well known company for the area
Free stuff working for a university (e.g., t-shirts, events)
cons:
I guess it can vary depending on department, but in my experience I’ve seen:

-high turnover
-heavy middle management with few admins who are overworked and treated as scapegoats. 
-toxic environment with management who believe that being tough is the best way to lead - even though people on their team keep leaving. 
-Management views you as a “worker bee” not someone they can invest in and develop. It’s a very one-sided transaction.
-admins are given zero support. You’re doing someone else’s work for them… so they will micromanage you to death until it’s done “their way”. Yet they refuse to communicate what their way is up front and expect you to read their minds. It’s maddening.

review_title: Once a great employer, but they no longer practice what they teach. Employees are just numbers.
pros: Steady work, low expectations for performance.
cons:
Pay and benefits have not kept pace with the rest of the State and Community wage increases. Cost of living is increasing faster than wages.
Culture and work climate is hostile compared to just 5 years ago. It used to be common to see employees with 30-40 years at Cornell keep working because they loved the community. Everyone I know is counting the days to retire ASAP and we have had a large number of employees leaving Cornell to work elsewhere for better pay, benefits, and reduced stress.
Covid really exposed the class structure at Cornell. The essential workers were on Campus every day and working without support as the Managers were all working from home (On Vacation!). My supervisor recieved a large pay increase, while we got a t-shirt and a slice of pizza. The FCS Managers are full of stories about home remodeling, and new hobbies they started during Covid. Many got to travel and were living in vacation homes during the pandenic. They answered emails and attended Zoom meetings from vacation sites. Many of the stay at home crowd are struggling now to use their accrued vacation time before they loose it. Essential workers were forced to use accrued time to deal with Covid related difficulties.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros:
Being a graduate teaching assistant is a very important opportunity for graduate students. Firstly, you can practice your teaching skills. Secondly, it gives you a chance to interact with undergrad. The mentorship experience is also helpful. 
Lastly, you can have some stipend monthly and the school will waive your tuition and pay your health insurance.
cons: The workload is various for different courses. I have TAed three courses. The bio lab course for Cornell freshmen is most time-consuming. It requires you to teach two labs every week. 3 hours for each one. You also need to attend the weekly prep meeting which is also 3 hours. Besides teaching, you also need to grade. The pay is higher than other TAs. It is about $1,800 every two weeks. Good pay for a graduate student.

pros: My manager cared about two things -- that we were doing our jobs well, and that we were doing well as people. Working for Cornell felt like the perfect balance between having a high standard of work and allowing for personal things that inevitably come up in life. There was paid time off for holidays, sick days, and personal days, all of which I was encouraged to take advantage of. Everyone I worked with was friendly and welcoming from the start -- truly a great place to work.
cons: The only reason I left was because I never intended to do administrative work long-term. There were certainly times when the job would get stressful, corresponding to the semester's schedule and the many events that are organized for students, but that wasn't what made me decide to leave my position.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Ithaca, NY
pros: There are a few way sot think about whether a paid/funded phd graduate program is worth it. (1) If you are dead set on being an academic. (2) if you are gaining transferable/technical skills, while getting paid to do research and study.
cons:
I would be weary of entered a paid/funded phd program in a field where you are not gaining technical/transferable skills (e.g. learning statistical analyses). Most academic jobs are hard to get, so if you spend 5 or 7 years making $30K, you should come out better off on the other end -- even if don't land an academic job.

Many academic advisors are great for helping you find jobs in academia. But completely useless (even if they have the best of intentions) for finding jobs outside the field (exceptions apply in fields, perhaps like economics or computer science, where there is more back and forth between academia and industry).

job_title: Licensed Veterinary Technician in Ithaca, NY
pros: Progressive policies, cutting edge research, great benefits, international community, beautiful campus, emerging leader in employee well-being
cons:
Chronically short-staffed with high turnover and a baked-in culture of poor self-care. 
 Mid-level management is extremely hit or miss at consistently applying policies and pursuing university goals. Some departments are wonderful to work in, but many, especially in the veterinary hospitals, are toxic dead-ends. Reporting structure is poorly organized mish-mash of official and unofficial supervisors. You'll feel like you have 8 bosses instead of 1 and who they are changes depending on the day and the hour and the task at hand. Senior management are trying, but it's slow and painful progress as many supervisors function like they still work in private practice, rather than managing employees to grow in their careers as part of an industry-leading organization.

pros:
Cornell is a diverse place of research and learning with incredible collaboration opportunities across the campus and across the world. With such a powerful brand, a career at Cornell opens doors in many unexpected ways. I have found a good work/life balance in my job and can work outside my job description to develop other interests.

Ithaca is a beautiful place to live, and I feel lucky every time I go outside -- in any season.
cons: At times, the bureaucracy is frustrating. "Big Red Tape" is no joke.

review_title: Cornell Catering, great for non-hotelies with open schedules
pros: Great way to gain backend experience in fine dining and exposure to well connected individuals. Also everyone got free gourmet meal at then end of their shift and pay was some of the best on campus.
cons: Schedules can change quickly based on event needs and managers are not always understanding of class conflicts. Heavy lifting and late nights are common. Additionally, very specific uniform requirements can be expensive to acquire and easily damaged with spillage and hard labor. Tips are not allowed.

review_title: Excellent workplace culture, pay could have been better given the area.
pros: Good work environment and decent benefits. It provided excellent experience toward an industry career, and the primary investigator overseeing the project was more than willing to see if the work appointment could be extended beyond its original end date.
cons: Employment was based on project funding, so employment was not able to be extended beyond a few extra months. Additionally, the rent prices in Ithaca are very, very high, so finding affordable housing for the pay rate was very difficult, and mostly limited to student neighborhoods.

pros: Fantastic institution to work at in Ithaca. It's great to be part of such an engaging and collaborative community working towards the goal of educating students to be lifelong learners and innovators. As an employee, you have access to incredible benefits like retirement plan, investment options, healthcare, gym (still charge for access), and courses.
cons: In higher education administration sometimes the needs of the office outweigh your professional interests so you should be aware of your long-term goals and stay committed to doing the work you want to do to keep growing as a professional in your desired field

pros: Many academic opportunities, great place to explore academic interests.  Supporting environment, lots of support for personal interets.  The university has diverse programs and offers top academic programs, in many varied field which you might not find anywhere else.  The phyiscial setting is great, lots of green space, nature views, the university is obviously committed to the environment, with change made all the time.  While some might find the lack of parking annoying, it encourages the use of mass transit.  I found my time there to be positive overall, many aspects of which I didn't appreciate until I had completed my time there.
cons: The academic environment can be very stressful.  Many times, it can feel like you do not measure up to their standards or cannot succeed there.  Support from the faculty, especially in acadmeic programs can be lacking, though some are more supportive than others.  This is greatly depenant on one's indivdual academic supervisor.  There is a sense that you never can escape work, and that you are never truly off the clock.   Ithaca is an isolated place.  Though there are many positive aspects to the town, it can be difficult to get out of town, as the closest major cities (New York and Toronto) are 4 hours away.

review_title: Lots of great opportunities and benefits, especially for the size of the community
pros: Cornell has a lot to offer.  It is the largest employer in the region and one of the only places where one can move from one department or role to another at the same employer.  The benefits, including sick and vacation time, are quite good.  Most of staff/faculty and the vast majority of students are wonderful to work with.  There is a lot of opportunity to learn and grow professionally and even personally.  There are issues and challenges here like anywhere (see below), but I am still optimistic and happy to work here.  As someone who experienced a layoff here, I can confidently state that they handled it in the best way possible.  I know corporate America would not have treated me so well as they let me go.  And brought me back.
cons: University leaders are out of touch with the rest of the staff, their needs & challenges.  While they seek to balance the budget after years of mismanagement, they let staff go and expect remaining staff to work 2 or more jobs.  In addition, it is such a large university it is almost impossible to guarantee consistency in promotions, job reviews, and policy enforcement across the campuses, or at least they have not figured out how to do it.  People are often promoted to managers without training or ability, and then no one wants to address the issues caused among the employees.

pros:
Cornell Dining is great for student workers because:
--you get free meals
--you meet a diverse group of people from different schools
--you really brush up on customer service and hospitality skills in ways that you can't in-class
--you learn to interact with both part-time and full-time workers
--you're constantly moving, so it's never boring
--you get to set your own hours
--you can move up the hierarchy if you work hard (and eventually become a student manager, which is GREAT experience)
--you feel like you're part of a family.

I loved working for dining, but there are some pitfalls (see cons' section).
cons:
Although Dining can be a great job, there are some pitfalls:
--Management is a bit of a mess. There's management for both the students and the full-time workers, so you're never too sure who you're supposed to report to
--The amount of work can differ between locations. Some dining halls are more laid-back with less work; others have a ton more even when you have the same shift. As a result, the responsibilities in the description don't reflect reality.
--Dining is broken up into divisions, so you may only be able to work for one group of dining halls. (Example: If you work at Trillium, you can work at Synapsis but not on West Campus.)
--The student employment office absolutely sucks, and even though you're reporting to a student manager, you're represented by them. I tried to submit a grievance, and they made it so difficult that I just let it go. Try to avoid them as much as possible and deal mostly with your actual employer, i.e. your student and dining hall managers.

job_title: Prospect Research Analyst in Ithaca, NY
pros: Top tier research institution, well managed HR processes, excellent benefits. Because of the size of the university there exists, for many people, lots of room for lateral and upward mobility. This is not the case for some specialized staff members unless they are willing to leave their chosen field, however.
cons:
One of the great things about Cornell is that it doesn't have a culture of firing people on a whim. So there isn't a looming cloud of fear about losing your job at the drop of a hat. The flip side is that this allows some people to get away without doing their jobs for extended periods of time. I've seen people get fired. But it often happens years after the problem was apparent and, even then, only after reassigning the person a few times to try to get them to work out in other areas. On the one hand it's good that they value people to the point of trying to find a proper "fit." On the other hand, imagine working with a person who got shuffled to their present position on their way out the door. 

Also, merit pay is incredibly low. Every year you can count on likely not earning more than a 2% cost of living increase no matter how well you perform.

review_title: Fierce Competition for Academic Positions and Not Many Opps for Non-Administrative Employees
job_title: Research Support Specialist in Ithaca, NY
pros: Great benefits; low cost gym membership; ILR school offers professional development funds; the University offers plenty of leadership and training opportunities both on campus and in NYC; Cornell University is one of the few Ivy league institutions that offer their employees an employee-degree program, where you can work and also obtain a degree if it falls in line with your current position.
cons: The job competition for non-PhDs is fierce because of the number of trailing spouses (and favortism) and former college students who stay in the area. Ithaca itself does not offer many opportunities for young professionals to develop their careers. I once worked in a department where all 3 administrative assistants had master's degrees. Our IT director had a JD. Even if you are "overly qualified" for a position, there are still many competitors and the department can be as picky as you want. If you're doing research in an academic field, there is only so far you can go without a PhD and there is high pressure for you to obtain the degree. Depending on your department, there can be a lot of internal politicking (as with any large bureaucratic work environment). Parking is slightly difficult considering that this is the largest employer in a 50 mile radius.

review_title: Too much management and too little opportunity!
pros: Benefits are on par with other comparable educational facilities which is very nice.  The University also offers flex working hours which will help families that need to be at home in mornings or early afternoons to help young children get on/off the school bus.
cons: Pay scale is below national average, below comparable educational facilities, and below what can be considered as cost of living in this region.  Taxes from being in New York State are monstrous and detrimental.  Roads fail every winter causing high vehicle maintenance.  Winter road salt corrodes your vehicles to a point where they need replacement every 4-7 years.  Working for the University and wanting to park on university will cost you for a parking permit beginning at $350 per month.  Don't ever park in the wrong place or you will receive a parking ticket beginning at $75 per infraction.  No discounts for family of faculty of staff to attend the university.  Job related training is reserved for a select few who typically management.  Professional organization memberships and training opportunities are discouraged by management.

pros: Depending on the school or unit that you are in, Cornell University can be one of the absolute best workplaces. Work-life balance, wellness initiatives, opportunities for learning and advancement, (including employee degree programs and other formal training), beautiful campus, and events for faculty, staff, and students to keep things alive and interesting. Pay and time off are great, especially when compared to other organizations in the area. The organization's mission and vision are compelling, and it is a wonderful feeling to be a part of an institution so focused on making the world a better place in so many ways.
cons: Certain areas within the university are plagued with managers who have been promoted to leadership positions without leadership ability, resulting in abusive supervision, low employee morale, and turnover. Reports to HR to attempt resolutions between ill-used personnel and their managers seem to be many, with few visible corrective actions taken. There also tends to be a tolerance for faculty elitism and viewing/treating staff as inferior, particularly in comparison to their faculty colleagues. Many areas within the university are also very prone to fiscal waste - spending money on meals, gifts, etc. that are really not necessary to maintain operations and that are technically not permitted.

review_title: One of the best options in the region
pros: The campus is beautiful, the benefits are great (at least through endowed colleges). As a staff person, you can check out library books for a whole year! There are opportunities for staff development. If you land in the right department with good people, working at Cornell can be great and pays well.
cons: The university is huge, and experiences in various colleges and departments can vary greatly. Many faculty have little "real world" experience and do not know how to conduct themselves in a professional manner (tantrums is a word that comes to mind). There can be a strange dynamic among staff, faculty, and the administration. There are lots of redundancies and inefficiencies in the systems Cornell uses to conduct business. (This includes the payroll/accounting systems and the redundant multiple systems for managing courses.)

review_title: Could improve greatly with attention to employee's satisfaction
pros: Intelligent workforce and community (overly qualified people are forced by limited opportunities in the community to work for Cornell), committed employees, beautiful campus (although it is constantly under construction), scenic Ithaca area with many restaurants, wineries, parks, and some cultural opportunities, easy commute with little traffic.
cons:
Cornell realizes it is the main game in town, so salaries are depressed and options for growth are sometimes limited. Upper administration is reluctant to rid itself of abusive supervisors, and permits employees to be over-worked, undervalued and belittled by poorly trained or overly ambitious managers. Cornell is facing severe financial constraints and is constantly asking employees to do more with less, leading to a stressed and unhappy workforce. 

Rents in Ithaca are very high compared to outlying areas.  Winters are very long, gray, and can be depressing.

review_title: Survey Research Institute a great place to work
job_title: Senior Research Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros: I started at Cornell's Survey Research Institute (SRI) in early 2019. I began as a temporary research assistant, working 10-15 hours a week. I thought it would be a dead-end job, but I ended up enjoying the people I work with and the fast pace office call center setting, and was able to apply for a promotion. I'm now working at SRI fulltime and love to interact with the fulltime staff as well as the temporary research assistants. I think it's a really fun and young group of people, which can be rare in a workplace. Management keeps employees interacting with each other with kick-off meetings before calling projects and a celebration when those projects are done. Management has also been proactive during COVID-19 to keep staff employed.
cons: Cold calling people on the phone is a difficult job and requires a lot of persistence. It's not the right job for everybody, and the learning curve with regards to the equipment functions and protocols to memorize is steep.

review_title: A Decent Education & An Unhealthy Work Environment
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Ithaca, NY
pros: Access to cutting-edge equipment and the opportunity to work with extremely talented people in a wide range of scientific, business, and artistic fields.
cons: As a graduate student, I experienced horrid management by professors:  employee infighting was encouraged, falsified data was pushed for publication, emotionally volatile/immature bosses were the norm. There was a lack of clear goals for every professor I worked with and unpaid overtime was the norm. We were promised jobs only if we did everything they said and constantly threatened if we stepped out of line or questioned a boss' decision. I saw the news of Title 9 inquires and student suicides surpressed and/or erased from public record. Cornell illegally funded opposition to a graduate student union and falsified votes. Be very careful when considering this school, they have many problems that are common in academia but unlike other schools I've worked in they don't seem to be interested in changing the status quo.

review_title: Graduate Student in the Physics Department
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Ithaca, NY
pros:
- Excellent resources for experimental physicists and engineers.  The nanofabrication facility (CNF) is outstanding, providing access to state of the art tools and expert advise from staff.  Cornell Center for Materials Research also has some great tools for microscopy, device characterization, and fabrication.

- Tons of talks and seminars accessible to students.  The graduate society is very active and organizes frequent social events.

- For a small town, Ithaca has a lot of great restaurants, hiking, and things to do.

- Stipend is reasonable.  Health insurance included.

- Welcoming environment for women and minorities.
cons:
- If you don't like the cold, you will have a bad time.  Winters can be pretty harsh, making travel difficult.

- Ithaca is far away from pretty much everything.

- This is mostly universal for grad school, but work life balance can be non existent at times.  Be prepared to spend late nights and weekends on campus.

- Housing can be a little expensive, especially if you want to live near campus.

- Career guidance for physics PhDs looking to pursue jobs outside of academia is basically nonexistent.  Career services occasionally has events, but they are poorly advertised.

- Food on campus is overpriced and not very good.

pros: Very passionate Phds, post-docs, researchers who care about their work
cons:
I can only speak about CLO’s tech offerings, but there is a huge, I’d even say delusional, gap between what the Lab offers and where the industry is as a whole. 

Coming from a competitive marketplace it was bizarre to sit in a room and hear grandiose platitudes about how skilled the team felt for using things like AWS, or Angular, or Node, or other technologies which have been in use for years at larger companies.  

This disconnect was something I could find amusing on certain levels, but staff was short, and managers could not wrap their heads around reality; their work does not appeal to anyone with an advanced degree in computer science. Properties like All About Birds, they’re good sites but small, small potatoes outside the non-profit realm and unappealing to anyone looking to advance professionally. I can only imagine someone taking such a position if family obligations required living in Ithaca, but instead of being realistic managers expanded the search and wasted time.

review_title: very informative experience, with hands on mentorship
pros: There are many resources available to you and Professors genuinely love their work. The students are bright, and for the most part very hard working. It is rewarding and you can see the result of your work in the students very quickly. There is good feedback from Professors regarding the quality of your work.
cons: Upper management from the university (above the departmental level) is very disorganized and often treats faculty and staff very poorly. There is limited communications between departments and university heads, and as the upper levels there is little care for the quality of education that the university should maintain. There is often a conflict of interest between faculty and staff that are trying to teach, and the business interests of the university. Often, the university would rather look good on the surface than really acknowledge underlying problems within the school.

job_title: Assistant to the Chair in Oxford, MA
pros: Like any company, your experience will vary depending on the department in which you work and your manager and co-workers.  I worked in two academic departments during my 10+ years at Cornell, and they were wonderful experiences.  I think the academic departments tend to be more laid back and easier to work for than the administrative offices, from what co-workers used to tell me.  People I worked with in my own department and across campus were generally friendly and helpful, a real pleasure.  There is, of course, the usual bureaucracy to deal with which many complain about, but having worked for other companies, it is really no worse than par for the course. Beautiful campus, tasty food in the dining halls, and wonderful people to work with.  I really miss Cornell.
cons: The only con I can think of is the parking.  I do not miss parking in A or B lots and taking the shuttle buses into the office.

job_title: Full Time Faculty in Ithaca, NY
pros:
Fantastic students, both undergrads and grads.
Brilliant imaginative faculty and staff.
A great deal of good education and new discoveries and ideas produced despite disastrous policy decisions by senior administrators.
cons:
Overpaid, less than competent senior administration
Staff who actually keep the lace running well excellent, the senior administration (titled, brass plates on door, etc.) make decisions in secret that are more often than not detrimental to the students, faculty and other staff. 
Corruption widespread in administration; value corporate and other large gifts over academic freedom and public service; accepts funding for centers and curriculum that advance corporate propaganda rather than critical thinking and contending ideas.
Secrecy, and general lack of transparency in administrative decisions
Com[lete disrespect of faulty and staff by central administration

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Ithaca, NY
pros: Wide variety of research areas, generally very collaborative and cross-disciplinary atmosphere, "Top-10" school, great location with good local culture.  Chemistry Department is rigorous.
cons: For the Chemistry Department... relatively narrow-minded outlook on future careers.  Principal Investigators mostly out for themselves, with little care for other PIs or research outside of their own area.  Graduate student life depends highly on the lab they join - some PIs respect a reasonable work-life balance, while most others expect the world to revolve around their research with little regard for students' families and personal life or interests.  Essentially no rewards/acknowledgements for meeting or exceeding expectations, as the expectations seem to be more and more.  Not uncommon to encounter individuals (including PIs) that will try intimidation techniques or flat out lie to manipulate others (i.e., for motivation purposes).

review_title: Great community, but a lot of bureaucracy
pros: The people in my department are wonderful to work with, I have good work life balance, and lots of friends from work. There is nothing like being on a university campus for having access to interesting events and like-minded people. I was also able to get a free degree through the employee degree program - definitely a pro given the current cost of masters programs.
cons: The bureaucracy is often so complicated that no one really knows how to navigate it. The HR department has not been helpful whenever I have needed their help and there have been some major issues over the years, particularly a missed paycheck and a lapse in benefits without a lapse in employment or a change in position. This leads even senior members of staff to make some errors. For example, my salary did not end up being what I was initially offered and, although I was promised a permanent rather than temporary position, my supervisors were actually unable to make that happen until 6 months in.

review_title: Great benefits but work-life balance issues
pros: Hard to beat the benefits and compensation for this region. In most divisions, there are opportunities for staff to advance. Lots of access to campus events and enrichment activities, even for staff who are not faculty.
cons: Expectations for staff to work (answer emails and put out fires) at all hours really burns out staff. I can't speak to the faculty/academic roles. Professional development for staff skill development can be tricky with such tight budgets. Many employees have been there a long time - because there are few comparable employers in the area – but skills don't necessarily keep up to date. This presents significant management challenges. Workload keeps growing for staff.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros: Graduate students at Cornell receive excellent benefits. This varies by department, but on the whole, we receive an education (with all tuition waived), health insurance, and a decent salary as far as graduate student positions go (I make ~$33,000; I made ~ $40,000 last year with the correct teaching assistantship).
cons: People say that Cornell is isolated; I love it, because I grew up in a small town and have ample opportunity to hike, canoe, kayak, fish, pretty much do anything outdoors. Other people hate Cornell's climate. Yeah, it gets cold. But if you embrace it, it's not too bad. Small price to pay for a top-notch education.

review_title: Depends what department you work in.
job_title: Administrative Assistant III in Ithaca, NY
pros: Good pay and benefits. Educational opportunities if you supervisor things it's of value...many don't.
cons: Low growth opportunities, not respected by most faculty, can't be problem solvers, no one follows the policies or requirement. Everything is an exception. When a problem arises the staff is the first to be blamed and the first to have their jobs reduced. Cornell itself has acknowledged  that their staff is unhappy but they leave it up to the colleges and depts to fix the problem you would think that the upper management would see that it's the middle layer that is causing a lot of the disharmony in the first place.

pros: Very diverse workplace with wonderful opportunities for advancement.  Abundant training and ease of information access on HR, benefits, and "how-tos".    Good comp and benefits relative to metro area.  Excellent resources for housing.  Leadership seems to care about employee morale.
cons:
Takes FOREVER to get anything done!  Lots and lots of red tape, budget restrictions, and time-consuming steps/paperwork that appears exclusive to CYA. 
Lack of focus to keep aging/senior workforce trained and current with systems (email, Workday, etc..)   
  Aging workforce and represented employees are underemployed and underutilized. 
 Managers and HR focus on attracting and recruiting "new" talent but seem to ignore wealth of skills and experience in existing workforce.

pros:
The people in the area in which I work are very mission-driven and dedicated, providing a great professional community. The students and employees are intelligent and hard working, and that makes going to work a fun challenge.

Benefits, including vacation time are very good. The University closes from right before Christmas to right after New Year, so that's a bonus on top of vacation time.

The employee degree program is great and many of my colleagues have benefited from that program.

Ithaca is beautiful (albeit the winters are long) and it's a wonderful place to raise a family.
cons:
In my opinion, pay is fairly low, and is consistent within pay bands. Salaries are flat: raises seem to be pretty much non-existent (I don't think I've been given even a cost of living increase for going on 10 years).  

Note that your experience positive/negative might depend where in the university you work.

review_title: Research has been exciting, and the community is very vibrant so after research time is also fun.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros:
Community is lovely - both Ithaca and the campus community. Lots of activities and clubs to get involved in if you want. Compensation is good at Cornell compared to other universities. The flu season gets crazy but otherwise, the campus healthcare is good. 

I'm satisfied with the research environment.
cons: Being a grad student is tough. Sometimes your advisor may not have your best interests in mind and it is very hard to challenge that because there is no organized 'grievance' committee that is ACCESSIBLE to all students. The director of graduate studies is supposed to do this but I see that he/she fails because they don't take the job seriously, and the title is given on a rotation basis rather than on merit.

pros: Working at the annual fund is great. They really value their student employers, and scheduling is super flexible. The evening hours are unlikely to conflict with most academic obligations, and it's easy to flex out of a shift or find another worker to sub for you if you have a prelim. And on the flip side, it's easy to work almost every day if you want to. They also buy callers who do well food on occasion, so that's a fun bonus. Overall it's a great place to work as a student!
cons: Over time they have become a bit more obsessed with metrics, which unfortunately coincides with fewer people picking up their phones due to an overabundance of spam calls. That said, your salary isn't based on any of those metrics. Also, on occasion, you'll talk to some angry people, but it's much less frequent than one would expect, or what would happen in any other client-facing position.

job_title: Student Employment Manager in Ithaca, NY
pros:
- Great development opportunities - staff may take courses taught at the University and managers may provide money for certifications and support other forms of growth
- Health benefits are very good and staff and faculty have access to gyms and fitness classes on campus
- The campus is very clean, safe and beautiful 
- There are lots of intelligent people and the atmosphere is fun and relaxed, occasionally stressed
cons:
- Some older works slow growth because they do not consider innovation
- For a University that prides itself on diverse ways of thinking some of the courses are pretty biases and might as well be called "How to be a Liberal"

review_title: Intellectual environment but limited growth potential and struggling local economy
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Ithaca, NY
pros: Cornell University is an amazing research university with leading professors, schools and programs, research institutes. The school has been going through a growth trajectory in its facilities and programs as a result of large grants from donors and alumni. Compensation is good for the Ivy Leagues. The campus is gorgeous in late Spring, Summer, and Fall.
cons: One of the largest challenges of working at Cornell's main campus in Ithaca is that it is very removed from the rest of the state and broader intellectual communities in Boston, NYC, and the mid-Atlantic. The university has difficulty bringing in the very best young talent because it takes a large commitment to move to upstate New York and raise a family. That being said, however, the young professors that do settle into the area truly love the slower pace of life and the very small intellectual community.

job_title: Administrative Assistant III in Ithaca, NY
pros: The pay  and benefits are good. Most of the employees are nice. There are educational opportunities,  you get to say you worked here which seems to impress people. You get different experiences for different department.
cons: Not enough staff recognition. Each dept, college and division is run differently, there is no consistency in rules or processing. Some staff have been there forever and are rewarded for flying under the radar. Does not encourage growth or out of the box thinking. A lot of people with power issues or people who are in leadership position who cannot lead. Can be very frustrating for people use to common sense. Faculty can be arrogant, it's very much a place on who you know to move.

review_title: Alumni Affairs & Development: A great place to settle...
pros: Cornell is the largest employer in the region so the benefits are excellent and there is international name recognition once they are on your resume. The lifestyle is stable and family friendly.
cons:
If you want any position other than the one for which you were originally hired, you will have to apply like an outsider and out compete hundreds of applicants from across the nation. There are no raises, no incentives and no promotions. If you want to move up, you have to apply and be interviewed (along with external applicants) by your own coworkers. Stagnation and lateral movement are the norm for employees.  Performance and loyalty are not recognized. 

If you move to Ithaca to take a position with Cornell and you want to advance your career, you need to be prepared to to move again.

job_title: Senior Program Coordinator in Ithaca, NY
pros: Gorgeous campus with world renown facilities, access to wellness programs, and interactions with peers who are remarkably talented and supportive.
cons: On the books, CU's all about an inclusive, supportive, responsive environment.  This usually holds in place a year or two, but after the first of many re-orgs, the reality can gradually become the reverse.  Across colleges, talented staff become hesitant to report issues, even in neutral exit interviews, related to uneven management.  Repercussions vary and can include unreasonable loads for extended periods of time or a slow but steady reduction of key responsibilities.   The title is eventually "updated" to a lower pay band.    HR's answer is to encourage staff to apply to any openings in a different college or department.

review_title: Cornell is a nice place to be a grad student
pros: Overall Cornell is a pretty good place to be a grad student, although of course your experience will heavily depend on your research group and your advisor. WIthin Engineering, most of the faculty are top notch and really know their stuff, and quite a few are literally the world leaders in their fields. Ithaca is a cool little funky town to be in for a few years, with lots of outdoorsy things to do and many good restaurants. The winter is pretty long and cold, but that helps you focus on your work. Also, go watch a hockey game while you're here.
cons: Cornell's administration is known for "Big Red Tape." If you have an administrative problem it can take several trips to several different offices around campus to get things figured out. Also there is not much in terms of campus housing for grad students, so most live off campus.

job_title: Student Supervisor (Dining Hall) in Ithaca, NY
pros: Work's not too difficult and most student managers are flexible and understanding about demanding schedules, as long as you make up the work. Most co-workers are cool people, too, so it's easy to make new friends.
cons: Can feel like a bit of a grind sometimes. Some students are very entitled to the point of being downright insulting, but the vast majority are just there to get their food. Pay isn't great, but for a student worker, it's generally helpful and the free meals with each shift is nice too.

review_title: Resident Advisor at Cornell Campus Life and Residential Programs
pros: Free room & board as a student, more benefits if returning for another year, such as discount on campus meal plan, free rental fridge and microwave in room, free program house fee (if at a program house), awesome student leadership training and access to copious campus resources and knowledge of campus departments to work with
cons: Bureaucracy of high level long-tern decisions seemed to go against the best interests of those at the bottom actually interacting with residents and students on the everyday basis (Resident Advisors, some Resident Hall Directors, those with a better sense of how the communities should be maintained).

pros: the people who work in my department are great. many have been here for decades. The benefits of being full time staff are great (health insurance, education, etc). Salaries are competitive.
cons: I think the culture among staff in the university's administration is one of frustration. growth opportunities are limited and it's impossible to get fired. Management is encouraged to keep everyone right around the middle (in terms of job evaluation), so they don't have to be bothered with employee improvement plans or promotions. I can't speak for other departments of course, but our managers are not good leaders. The students of CU are the purpose of our work, but the message from the top seems to be that they are constant source of annoyance and disruption. I have a lot of potential, but I never get the sense that my management is interested in fostering the development of that potential.

review_title: A dream job for academics, and a lot of bang for your buck.
job_title: Associate Professor, College of Engineering in Ithaca, NY
pros:
Among the top engineering schools in the country, Cornell as a member of the Ivy League is a place where the University mission does not sacrifice any of the major pillars of a world-class university: (1) -all- areas of study are important to the University's mission; (2) high-quality research -and- teaching (both grad and undergrad) are both important to the University's mission.

Salary and benefits are very good, especially considering the cost of living.
cons: Location a bit remote from major cities. Health care substandard (ironically, Cornell is a medicine powerhouse in NYC). State, property, and school taxes are steep.

review_title: Cornell-great school if you want an academic job.
pros: Lots of smart people...the undergrads can be a handful sometimes, though.  The benefits package is good - it's surprisingly nice to be able to have most of one's health needs handled at the school's clinic on campus.  During the summer, Ithaca is absolutely spectacular.
cons: Bureaucracy can be enraging; to much organizational inertia for things to change very quickly. I imagine there is significant variation in the way graduate students are treated across departments, but I have not heard anything specific. Winter here can definitely get old - I am from a southern state, so it took a season to learn how to deal with it.  However, I almost like it now.

review_title: Prestigious University that mostly lives up to its reputation. But some weaknesses that may be department-specific
job_title: Assistant Professor In the Life Sciences in Ithaca, NY
pros: Reasonable decent salary for faculty, great benefits. The health insurance plan is superb and very affordable. Retirement benefits are quite good too, especially if you work for the statutory arm of the University where you get NY state retirement benefits.
cons: The biggest con of this place is its isolated location surrounded by farms and small hamlets. The nearest biggest city is Syracuse at an hour away and NY City is 5 hours away. Philadelphia is 3 hours away. No truly big city is less than 3 hours from here. Rural location in the middle of no where can be a damper!

job_title: Medical Assistant in New York, NY
pros: I loved the patients,  they were so nice and when ever they came to the office they always  ask how was it doing and they asked  about my family  is really miss them.
cons: Management treated the staff  like ( 3 ) year  olds , giving people  titles  and they don't  have the education  or credentials every one wanted to be BOSS , everyone  was an adult we didn't  need for people  to tell usomeone when  to eat and not to talk  just was there for ( 7 ) years and it kept  getting  worse .

review_title: Good graduate programs in physics/astronomy (relative to others like it)
pros: High salary relative to cost of living. Good policies that many other comparable programs don't have, like good family leave and medical leave policies. Great health insurance. The committee system is good, and there are ways to be able to go around your adviser if you have a bad one, so that you aren't left isolated and alone in a bad situation. Very, very easy to take classes in any department and collaborate with anyone.
cons: Very high stress. Academia isn't really for me, so I probably had a harder time than some.

pros:
Fantastic benefits packages, including wellness-focused fringe benefits
Beautiful main campus, and easy travel to other campuses with university-run bus service to NYC
Lots of opportunities for employee recognition and professional development
cons: This is a large-decentralized institution where communication is inconsistent and difficult at best. There is a cultural fear of major change and small decisions take years to be made. Staff are often overlooked and can be left in the shadows of the faculty and students. It is a great place for professional development and gaining experience, but it is not the ideal place for a young professional to stay long-term.

pros: Great benefits and stable work, those are the two constants across campus (more on this below).  For me it's been great, my manager listens to me, I make good money, I have a challenging and fulfilling job.  There is a lot of flexibility when feasible.
cons: It's more like a small city than a single employer, so there is a lot variance between units and positions.    Some people work hard and enjoy what they do, others warm chairs and are bored.   My experience has been great, others not so much. It's very hard

review_title: Hard-working, collaborative, productive environment with lots of chances to enjoy nature
pros:
Extremely collegial - lots of chances to gain mentorship experience
Motivated workforce - if you are interested in working hard, you will not be alone
Excellent campus - Ithaca is one of the best college campuses in USA. It has continually been voted the best college town, two years in a row
cons:
Winter - Extremely long and cold - but if you survive the first one you will get through the next 3 or 4. Also you will realize how much weather effects our professional psyche
Location - While it has an amazing campus, its still far away from big cities and therefore attending professional events is a slight challenge.

review_title: I felt I was able to find a work-life balance here.
job_title: Research Support Specialist in Ithaca, NY
pros: Diverse workforce, great learning opportunities, supportive of families, wonderful parental leave policy, wonderful childcare grants, really nice amounts of vacation time.
cons: While this is a complaint I have had about other universities at which I have worked, I find it disagreeable that when living in a largely rural environment that I should have to pay ever greater amounts of post-tax money to park at work.  If this were not enough, it is my understanding the the university's policy is actually to REDUCE the number of parking spots over the future.  Finding it unconscionable to put this financial burden on the employee, I would park off campus and walk a half-mile to my building.  This made my 7 mile commute a 40-50 minute trip each way.

review_title: Great place to go to school
pros:
- Ithaca is nice small town with lots of really amazing people from all over the world, good restaurants, and plenty of outdoorsy stuff to do
- Cornell is an amazing school and I love the culture. People are very friendly and supportive. Because the school is so highly rated funding has never been an issue for me, which means I'm free to do research without having to worry about summer internships
cons:
- School is not as well connected to industry (computer science at least) as other schools like MIT, the california schools, or schools in WA
- Ithaca is a bit isolated, taking 4.5 hours to get to New York by car
- Not a lot of night life, only a few bars to hit
- If you're single and male the odds are against you

review_title: Mixed bag, some good, some bad.
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Ithaca, NY
pros: Cornell is a nice community. Ithaca, despite being a small town in the middle of nowhere in central New York, has a lot going for it. Cornell pays its grad students well, though cost of living is higher here than it would be in a small town without the university in this area. Public transportation is good for a small town (in that it exists at all), but isn't comparable to what you'd find in an actual city.
cons: Cornell is in the middle of nowhere. Grad students in some departments, or working for some PIs, are treated like dirt, kept here for too long than should be allowed (seven, eight, or more years sometimes), and sometimes without pay. Many departments don't disclose where their students find employment.

pros: This is a great school in that it teaches you alot about not only your major but working in general. I'm not just talking about career services, either. Through the academic program you will learn to work your ass off like no other, and with your friends by your side you may even enjoy it.
cons: The problem, however,is the people here are quite vacuous. Everyone tries to game the system (no academic brilliance is found here) and no one forms true friendships or relationships. This is because Cornell, in my opinion, overworks its students, and the people here are all academic climbers and care more about stepping on each other on their way to the top than wasting their precious time on forming real relationships with one another.

review_title: Decent place for work, not that great for much else
pros:
Cornell is a great research institution, and you will meet and work with world-class professionals daily. Also a recognized brand for your CV, and they pay OK to live comfortably in Ithaca.

Ithaca is pretty charming and has great water-falls and hikes.
cons:
The weather in winter.

The general population is a lot less social than other universities, and the town is very boring and in the middle of nowhere. 

Flying out or driving out is a huge pain, and you will have to do both for conferences/jobs/escaping the boredom.

There is next to no support for postdocs. Your experience may vary wildly.

Finally, the university has a *massive* bureaucracy problem. Nothing ever gets done, and you are not allowed to do it yourself.

review_title: Good faculty with mixed management abilities.
pros:
Speaking as a graduate student I can say that Cornell is a place with very knowledgeable and respected professors. While the interactions between advisers and students greatly depends on the professor style of work (some work shoulder to shoulder with their students, and others rarely visiting the laboratories) it is easy to meet and discuss problems with faculty that are not directly connected with your research. This is due to the policy of "Open doors" that Cornell encourages. The interactions between different departments are quite fluent and the sharing of ideas is considerably facilitated.
In general the staff is very supportive towards the students and helps overcome problems outside the academics.
cons: Considerable workload given to the graduate students.

pros: Retirement, some perks, medical, dental, life insurance, fellow workers get along pretty well, student workers are good workers, student workers are good workers.
cons: Horrible Management, moving towards corporate environment, external company dictating how we work, management treats worker like children, Union does nothing for the worker, lousy workers are more protected than good workers, one has to really screw up to get fired, experience counts for nothing, chef is walking on egg shells, low moral, forced to used vacation time over long breaks, for example, semester break. Leadership is the worst I have ever seen. Upper management is  on its way to controlling everything we do, no freedom, no imagination allowed when it comes to cooking food. This is one of the absolute worst places I have ever worked at.

review_title: PhD Student - Dyson School of Applied Economics
job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Ithaca, NY
pros: Enjoyable work environment, professors care about you, learn tools that will help you succeed as a researcher and on the job market. Some professors are especially committed to helping you succeed.
cons: At times poor communication within department (concerning policies, expectations, etc.). Financial support same size even for PhD students with families (providing health insurance for family members would help immensely, but alas is not offered).

pros: Postdocs on the Endowed side of the University are treated very well.  University contributes an extra 10% of base salary to a retirement account (you are not required to match contribution), very affordable and good health care, free bus pass, free parking if you carpool with one other person (including a spouse), free access to the university gyms, ability to take classes.  Also, I loved living in Ithaca.  It's an especially great place to live if you have a family.
cons: Great speakers do come, but not as many or as often as in major research hubs in big cities.  Also, Ithaca is cold in the winter.  If you like big cities, Ithaca will feel a little provincial and isolated.

review_title: PhD student, Biomedical Sciences - lots of flexibility
pros: Tons of flexibility to tailor your training to your own interests/needs. I really don't know of any other program like that. No require courses (except a career development and ethics course). Get to spend your first year rotating through 3 labs to find a good fit. Time commitment, workplace environment/culture, etc., is really based on what lab you choose, so just choose one that suits you! Guaranteed stipend, so although you are encouraged and supported to submit grants, that doesn't have to be your main focus (and you don't have to do it until your first year in, compared with other programs that require you to come with your money!)
cons: None, really. I have no complaints or concerns

pros: Lively intellectual community with a strong "open door" policy, even among extremely prominent and successful researchers. Not a toxic or competitive workplace for early-career academics and graduate students, which is a rare thing at Ivy League institutions.
cons: It's a large institution, and there are downsides to working at large universities in terms of access to personal resources or policy flexibility. Some administrators are a joy to work alongside and some are not. Cornell's response to sexual harassment complaints is extremely unacceptable and is the most urgent avenue of improvement.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Ithaca, NY
pros: The graduate stipend is very competitive among other major engineering schools.  My department is very supportive and goes out of its way to provide a balanced experience for students.  The programs at Cornell are very individualized so you are not saddled with the burden of having to take unnecessary classes just to pass comps.
cons: The weather is a big downside, as is its location in rural upstate New York.  The individualized programs mean that you have to be very proactive in seeking out what you need.  Everything is decentralized meaning that it can be very difficult to figure out who to talk to regarding a particular issue.

pros: Cornell University provides an incredible resource for postdocs - there are so many bright, motivated people on campus, and there is an office for postdocs that is a great source of information, training and support in terms of career development.
cons: Cornell University is a high intensity research university, and as such, many of the principal investigators that lead research groups here are workaholics. It often amplifies the difficulty in achieving a work-life balance.

review_title: Good employer in a great location
pros: A great place to work if you can be flexible and don't expect a lot of hands-on management. The university as an institution is a wonderful place, and there are a lot opportunities to grow. Reviews that criticize the location in Ithaca are mostly from young, student workers who hail from big cities.  Ithaca is a beautiful, vibrant community with so much going on you could never do it all. It is a terrific place to raise a family, and as long as you aren't looking for a club scene or brand-name shopping, you will be happy.
cons: Faculty do not usually make good managers. The work at an ivy league institution can be overwhelming at times.

review_title: Cornell has helped me grow substantially as a researcher and educator, and has given me ample opportunities to succeed.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros: Very flexible work schedule and location, plenty of independent work, easy access to faculty and advisor, good computing resources, easy access to health care providers, many opportunities for professional development on campus
cons: Health care is a little below average, each person's experience will be different depending on the fit to their advisor, can have too much independent work at times, guidance is often lacking if you don't realize you need it

pros: Excellent Benefits package. Ithaca has a diverse population due to it being a College town - comes with diverse food (so many restaurants), plenty of things to do for recreation if you like the outdoors, true 4 seasons if you like that kind of thing.
cons:
Isolated town, can be lonely. Challenging environment for people of color. Sense of isolation can be enhanced.

Far removed form the larger cities so may not have access to many things  - specific services, food, etc.

review_title: Beautiful on the outside, ugly on the inside
pros: Excellent benefits and work/life balance. Beautiful setting.
cons: Like every company, it depends on who you report to. Lack of accountability in management, particularly with "trailing spouses" who won't be held accountable if they are toxic, bad managers because of their spouses position. Elitism is alive and well.

review_title: WIC management are incompetent and not trustworthy.
pros: Most of the people are very professional and nice to work with.
cons: The office is extremely disorganized,  policies are not followed as directed by the state. Management lacks knowledge, organization, compassion and leadership qualities.

pros: If you're a professor, it's a great place to work. Salaries are generous and the administration takes a completely hands-off approach.
cons:
Anybody expecting a champagne and brie environment is going to be cruelly disappointing. I witnessed crude behavior by professors, even including fiddling with their crotches at meetings (and not just on 1 or 2 occasions). I over-heard professors verbally abusing graduate students.

If you're not a professor, the salary and benefits are below average.

I had to work on more than 90 percent of the weekends while I was at Cornell (including Memorial Day weekend and Labor Day weekend). I had to spend time at the office on the 4th of July, Labor Day, Thanksgiving, and Martin Luther King's birthday.

Cornell is very much the old boys network. Women are under-represented in the faculty and Afro-Americans are massively under-represented in both the faculty and the student body.

review_title: An amazing place for a few years of dedicated work
pros:
- access to some of the most brilliant people you will ever work with
- a dynamic intellectual environment
- frequently in close proximity to any number of visiting scholars, entrepreneurs, artists and others doing evocative work.
cons:
- often myopic view of how far into society such privileged conversations actually flow.
- true lack of understanding how intimately academia and industry need one another.

review_title: Well paid for graduate student salaries, academic life is bountiful
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros: Access to high quality eduction, plethora of extra curricular events, world renown experts whether at the university or invited, decent food options, and name recognition.  Ithaca is a nice town to live in, albeit slightly expensive for the middle of nowhere.
cons:
Ithaca is isolated from the rest of society -- NYC is a 4 hour drive minimum.  Food options on campus are quite limited when late or during breaks. 

As a graduate student, our status within the university is in a quantum superposition state between student and employee. Benefits are limited, and representation is minimal.

Also, graduate life can be brutally taxing on work/life balance. True almost anywhere, though.

review_title: The quality of the employer completely depends on the lab or department you're working.
job_title: Student Laboratory Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros: I only worked here as a student, but for student employees the university was great at recognizing the need for students to have flexible hours.  I happened to be in a great lab, but other people have had horror stories, though they usually weren't employees but also getting credit.  Considering I had many classes with university employees using their tuition remission, I would say that is a great benefit of the university as well.
cons: The quality is variable depending on the lab.  It's hard to say something as a whole to the university, because there are so many departments and employees.

pros: Benefits, no long hours, fellow employees are friendly
cons: Dining: Poor management,  Poor leadership, Too may chiefs, unorganized, management shows favoritism towards those in its clique, advancement not based on talent or experience, it is based on those that brown nose, does not reward employees, chefs do not work well together, poor teamwork among chefs, Poor/non-existent training, very few good cooks, pay does not match skill or experience of cooks, they either over payed or under payed, laziness is tolerated and fault is found with hard working cooks, no overtime, Union does absolutely nothing for the worker, cannot strike if we wanted to, Union is just a dues collecting agency.

review_title: This was a tremendous learning experience, it exposed me to cultures for which I was unfamiliar previously.
pros: Working with the residents proved joyous beyond what I could have expected. While this was a diverse population, I learned that all people have the same need.....to be treated with respect and love.
cons: Administration proved that problems which begin at the top are followed throughout the entire company. There was a lack of communication and trust.

review_title: Fun way to get through college
pros: Working here is a lot of fun. The people are great to work with and are always striving to be their best. It's an absolutely beautiful area to be in, especially if you like nature and the outdoors.
cons: It is a big place, so you don't really get to meet too many people.  The weather is cold most of the year and is in general not the best (though if you like the cold, it's not really a big problem). Ithaca is kind of out in the middle of nowhere, but luckily Cornell has enough stuff going on around it that it's not so bad.

pros: Great benefits, good salary for academia, nice progressive small city (Ithaca) that is really beautiful 6 months out of the year.  Superior opportunities to further one's education through the Employee Degree program.  Surrounded by a vibrant university community and generally smart, decent people who believe in the institution's mission.
cons: The pace of change can be glacial in most units.   Opportunities for advancement to senior level positions and institutional control are limited for non-academics.  Ithaca winters are long and gray.  Lots of politics.  State supported "contract colleges" are not immune to economic downturns and downsizing.

pros: gained laboratory experience for later jobs. learned some basics of cloning and molecular techniques and almost got to publish a paper although that depends on your lab
cons: the hours are weird and it all depends on how much you want to work. you can work as much or as little as you want depending on how much you want done. i list this as a downside because i like to have a fixed predictable schedule so if i want to plan on something like a dinner reservation, i can count on it.

pros: Got to see loads of movies for free! + free popcorn on your shift. Everyone was a lot of fun to work with, and you get great special event perks.
cons: You gotta sit in a booth alone for a four hours or more which can get a little tedious if you're not digging the film you're showing. A bit of pressure on you to get the change over timings, etc. so if you don't handle pressure well this may not be for you.

review_title: Great place to get a grad degree
pros: Beautiful city, great university. Lots of research is going on here, so it's easy to get support for almost any project that you are working on.
cons: Cornell could work on support for grad students with kids. Childcare is quite expensive in this city, and their maternity leave policy looks good on paper, but in reality it becomes difficult to implement so most students end up with zero time in paid support.

review_title: Cold in the winter, weird in the summer, good research in the spring and fall.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros: Departments are very open to grad student exchange and collaboration. Egos are relatively compact. People are brilliant, research facilities are extremely good.
cons: In the middle of nowhere. Travel times are ridiculous. No decent careers available for spouses, and very little feedback or fertilization from industry. Little contact with political power networks. Tuition is high, which does not affect grad students out of pocket, but certainly puts downward pressure on budgets and available research jobs.

review_title: Overall, very interesting and exciting place to work but with some areas of major frustration
pros:
Leading academic institution -our students, faculty and alumni are the best there is.
Very good benefits
Very rewarding to work at a place that is literally changing the world for the better
cons:
Higher education = a lot of bureaucracy and red tape
Not as innovative or entrepreneurial as you would think
Very slow to make change
Pay is very good in Ithaca but well below market in other cities (NY, CA, DC, etc)
Not enough "new blood" in leadership. Most people have been here their whole careers

pros: Beautiful campus and great wineries around the region. Daily shuttle bus to/from NYC if you want to visit the big city.  Work hours tend to be very regular and management is open to flex time for salaried employees. Great skiing within 1-hour drive.
cons: Area tends to be overcast and 'grey' most of the year. Cold weather and snow. Campus has significant parking problems and you have to pay a premium for preferred parking -- or park in the free commuter parking lot and ride the shuttle bus.

review_title: Strong Work Environment, Weak Social Life
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros: World class faculty and equipment for scientific research, with a variety of courses in different fields to supplement your working knowledge. People also attend conferences frequently which helps with networking.
cons: Ithaca, NY can be lonesome. There are few activities to partake of, and even worse, few people stick around during off hours to socialize. The winters are also cold and full of snow, but it's something you get used to.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Ithaca, NY
pros: A charming campus with amazingly, beautiful pastoral countryside. A trail runners dream come true! Cornell has a close community of friendly people. A lot of cultural development and much exposure to potential jobs, and important role models. Attend seminars and talks by important people to broaden your outlook on life. The benefits are good.
cons: Ithaca is a small town and often not suited to those individuals who need a busy city life. Its a tough, competitive life if you study here and be prepared to deal with some professors who are not there to help you but are there to have you do their work.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros:
-There are a few people high up in the administration that really care about making Cornell a more inclusive, safe place. I just wish there were more of them.
-Higher than average grad stipend and year-round health insurance, but no dental or vision
cons:
-Toxic work culture with a focus on prestige and appearance rather than quality research 
-Abuse, both sexual and emotional, from students and professors
-Title IX and ombudsman office are understaffed and the processes in place to report assault or abuse are time consuming and triggering
-Outdated scientific equipment in many labs
-Working in isolation for years with no feedback on performance or career advancement opportunities
-High cost of living in and around Ithaca, NY

review_title: Hard work but mostly worth it
pros: Very prestigious (good for applying to jobs), and lots of very smart people (good for making connections). The research facilities are generally good, and the campus is beautiful.
cons: Because of the prestige and general intelligence, expectations are very high and you are expected to do a lot of hard work. The winters are long and harsh too, which can add to the stress.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros: Great scientists to collaborate and get feedback from. Lots of resources from teaching workshops, BEST program, writing and communication workshops for career development and a lot of the world's best scientists come to give talks, which is great!
cons: slightly isolating environment at the same time.. it is hard to engage socially, i think because Ithaca is a quiet community. Also isolated from the big cities, so it is hard to network and eventually find jobs for graduate students interested in industry jobs.

pros: Cornell is full of interesting and smart people. Work is generally challenging and there is adequate recognition for a job well done. The pay and benefits at Cornell are comparable, if not better than the majority of other large employers in the area.
cons:
Your experience will most likely depend on your managers and your immediate group of coworkers. 

It can be very difficult to get hired, but once you are in the door it is much easier to move to different positions or roles within the university. 

Parking is expensive and often requires a long walk to your office .

review_title: "Good place to work for students, but politics run rampant"
pros: The work load you have is really up to you, you can take very little work, or can do more by getting more involved with the programs the office runs.  Co-workers are friendly.
cons: Politics of office create an oppressive atmosphere, many people don't voice their opinions because of fear of being politically incorrect (far too much worry that someone will get hurt here).  Management of many student programs is horrible because there's just too much for one person to do, and some programs get pigeonholed in favor of larger, more reputable ones.

review_title: Many great people and great resources, but poor oversight of the PhD experience
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros:
Excellent support resources for career development
Ithaca is a great town to live in
World class research
Many very talented, motivated, and dedicated faculty
cons:
Payroll doesn't send out paychecks on time
Too much power is in the hands of PhD students' research supervisors (advisors)
The quality of instruction is mixed -- can be quite poor in STEM

pros: Cornell University provides excellent benefits to faculty and staff, including good retirement plan options and pretty decent health insurance coverage. Salaries are good (especially given the cost of living in the area).
cons: Ithaca is in the middle of nowhere. If you place any value of having access to good shopping and an active dating scene, Ithaca is not the place for you. However, it is a good city for raising a family.

review_title: Great place to get a job, but no so much a career.
job_title: Student Assistant II in Ithaca, NY
pros: It's an Ivy league institution, so it's prestigious and the pay is good for the area. If you are involved with the community, it's a great place to be.
cons: It's a higher ed institution, so expect a lot of work surrounding the professors. Too much red tape because all the departments/professors are like separate entities. Could streamline the culture/system here to make a better place to work.

pros: They care about your wellbeing as a student and help you maintain a healthy balance between work and school. They teach you skills such as how to promote mental health and how to organize programs.
cons: The workload can be overwhelming at first. Each residence hall is unique, and training cannot prepare you for every possible scenario. You may encounter some problems that you did not expect, but other people are more than willing to help.

job_title: Project Associate I in Trumansburg, NY
pros: Great educational and professional opportunities for faculty, management and student staff. Steady work environment.
cons:
