Lack of educational and professional opportunities for individuals that are not faculty/management/student staff. Basic benefit packages have been shrinking since 2008 due to national economic recession, lack of donations and lower NSF/NIH grants. Pay rises are below the yearly 3% cost-of-living increases for most departments.  Older work force being forced out with early retirement incentives while using students to fill vacant positions at pay rates 15% to 20% below national average. Everything on-campus cost money to use, i.e. wellness program, parking, food, bus passes, etc, essentially nothing is free for non faculty/management/student staff. Cornell does not compensate employees for tools/services required for performing job, i.e. cellphones, internet access if working remotely, etc.  

Off-campus economy within Tompkins County is driven by Cornell University. Rent/housing, cars, food services, etc. are inflated to take advantage of students and certain staff that are cash rich. Crime is on the rise due to economic segregation, i.e. google 'jungle, Ithaca, NY',  'heroin, Ithaca, NY' or 'low income housing, Ithaca, NY'. Must own vehicle to get anywhere. 

tl/dr: On-campus is Disney like utopia; Off-campus resembles any major inner city environment.

review_title: Postdoctoral Researcher - Department of Neurobiology & Behavior
pros: Strong departmental solidarity. Cornell is a beautiful campus. Smart people. Laid back atmosphere, though strong work ethic. A great place to work, depending on your advisor.
cons: A little bit clique-ish. The campus is spread out so you have to travel long distances to get to HR buildings, etc. Otherwise I would recommend a job at Cornell to anyone.

review_title: Take the good with the bad - Mechanical Engineer for CLASSE
job_title: Research Support Specialist II in Ithaca, NY
pros: The work content is great, challenging, exciting, and always evolving. The people are pleasant to work with,  driven, and very knowledgeable. Great vacation and sick day policy. Great creative and general freedom in the workplace.
cons: The pay is laughable and you are typically responsible for many more things than you would be if you were in industry.

pros: I really enjoyed my time at the Cornell university library. I got to work with great people and do really fun and interesting projects. Everyone I met was excited about their work and helpful.
cons: The library is very old school and resistant to change. It's hard to get some people to see the new and better ways of doing things that technology allows us. Some staff members have been working there for decades. This probably isn't as much of a problem any more with the staff reductions that happened after the recession but still could be.

review_title: Fantastic Place to Work, Especially in the Summer
job_title: Temporary Service Professional in Ithaca, NY
pros: Dynamic work environment, talented grad-students, and a fantastic community.  Nice perks within the university as well, such as Microsoft Office, among others.  As an employee there is also great access to the COE, which has rentals for a variety of outdoor gear including kayaks.  They offer some pretty exceptional classes as well, such as Ice Climbing, which in the Ithaca area is on legal through the University.
cons: As Cornell University is a world class institution, folks are extremely busy, so at times it can be difficult to connect with others.

review_title: Great opportunity, but be prepared for commitment.
pros: Great resources, enthusiastic and capable staff, faculty, and peers. You will learn a lot, build connections, publish, and develop professionally. Work is rewarding but intense. Supervisors are strict but enthusiastic and interested in seeing you succeed.
cons: Work is intense with high expectations, primarily geared towards publication. In order to succeed, you must be willing to work hard and put other time-consuming goals or hobbies on hold. Mediocre levels of commitment are not tolerated.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros: It's easy to get promoted, the staff and students are friendly, and there are lots of benefits (maternity, paternity, retirement, etc.).  Plus, the Ithaca area is very health-conscious, facilitating your own health.
cons:
We are ~1h from all major highways, making travel in- and out- of Ithaca somewhat of a pain.
"Ithacating" is a form of weather characterized by random bouts of rain, snow, sleet, and slush.  However, it's absolutely gorges (pun intended) most other times!

pros: It depends on the course, but helping to teach a class is something I find very rewarding, particularly when I get the opportunity to help younger students explore the subject. The hours are also quite flexible, which is nice.
cons: The pay isn't too great -- after all, we're just undergraduate students. The "raises" are really just a quarter, not really that much to look forward to.

pros: Good benefits package including a generous retirement contribution. Generally progressive  mindsets throughout faculty and staff, and the beauty of the Ithaca area.
cons: Took many months to get hired. Too many meetings that mostly spiral into gossip. Shirking behavior around every corner, from every level. Chained to desk antiquated work environment. Too much waste, and way too many people walking around who think they are way too important.

review_title: Cornell Fitness Centers is a great place to work and exercise.
pros:
- Short Shifts (2-3hrs) that are easy to fit in around class schedules
- Free Gym Membership
- Lot's of Locations around Campus
- Easy to Move Up to get raises and promotions that put you higher on priority when schedule  is made
- Paid training
- Students can move up and hold assistant management positions
cons:
- Can be boring at times (stay motivated, makes friends with regulars to keep it interesting)
- Not allowed to do homework on the shift

review_title: I was a Cornell student and worked as a PlottingTA for the architecture department.
job_title: Plotting TA, AAP in Ithaca, NY
pros: It is great in helping with the everyday expenses of college, especially for a work study student. The job is quite light and there is opportunity to work on school work during the work hours. Additionally it helps with knowing how to print yourself, so when review times come you can resolve glitches and print your own material faster.
cons: Sometimes hours may not be considered enough (5 per week). Additionally when review times come around printing for others may become stressful as technology issues arise.

job_title: Research Support Specialist III in Ithaca, NY
pros: Absolutely wonderful to work in an academic environment with a focus on extending the bleeding edge of technology and science.   Smart people, driven, usually very enjoyable.
cons: Salary is very low compared to industry...factors of nearly 2 or more.  Tough to raise a family, impossible to send your kids to college on these salaries.  Rather ironic.  Half tuition benefit is irrelevant with such a low salary.

review_title: This place really cares about its employees
job_title: Marketing and Outreach Coordinator in Ithaca, NY
pros:
-Cornell knows to attract top talent (who may otherwise choose NYC or bigger cities) they must offer pretty good benefits. I am significantly more prepared for retirement after having worked at Cornell.
-You will grow  significantly as a professional. As an Ivy League institution, they expect you to perform as if you are in an Ivy League institution.
- You are working with incredibly intelligent people.
- Cornell has enough money to invest in larger projects that might not be possible in other universities.
- You'll meet amazing people doing amazing work from all over the world
-Ithaca is a charming town (as long as you don't need the stimulation of a big city.) The vineyards around Ithaca are wonderful. :)
- You have access to all facilities at Cornell AND all the free lectures you would ever want to attend!
cons:
-Cornell is both incredibly decentralized and hierarchical, based off of your email, the entire university knows what band (how much you get paid) you are in and it does sometimes feel that the amount of respect that you are given is based off of that band
-There is quite a bit of "town and gown" happening at Cornell. Since it is one of the central places for people to work around the area, there can be some aggression between younger staff (who come to Cornell to improve their resume) and older staff who feel under-appreciated in their current work environment.
-It can be very hard to move up in your specific unit, if you want to advance your career at Cornell you will most likely need to move units (Cornell does encourage that though! Every staff member I worked with, moved within Cornell to Associate Director positions!)
-Cornell is isolated there is no way around that. There are a lot of people that enjoy the isolation of Ithaca, but it is hard for a single person to find their bearing there.

job_title: Senior Teaching Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros:
generally friendly faculty
comfortable atmosphere
inquisitive students
engaging environment
intellectually stimulating
feel compelled to understand well enough to explain
great interpersonal experience
prepare you to think on your feet
cons:
unable to work overtime
uncompensated for extra hours
other teaching assistants tend to sit back and let others do their job for them
students sometimes seem out to beat one another
sometimes not a collaborative environment

pros: Job was well-paid and had great benefits (free summer housing near the working location, opportunity for over-time during large conferences). Excellent team, easy to get to know co-workers, flexible hours.
cons: Should have more opportunities to take on more hours. Conference planners are very nice and have great management over employees, but not as willing to delegate more responsibility to conference assistants/students.

pros: Cornell offers competitive compensation packages as compared other top tier institutions. Work environment is also  welcoming and enjoyable. Additionally,  summertime outdoor  is fanatic.
cons: Ithaca which is where Cornell University is located is a small town. When  school is out of session it  is more like  a ghost. However, it could be  bearable if you have a clique of friends or family

pros: Has excellent atmosphere and resources. Quite place to live. The staff is friendly and polite. Depending on your style of life Ithaca can either be charming or boring place to stay. But people do come back to this town. Plus 30000 students creates nice atmosphere and some extra possibilities for business.
cons: Your work strongly depends on academic funding which affects mostly all domains. Some jobs can sustain few years, while others can live longer. Working in academic environment can be relaxed, but at the same time requires you to remember about real world.

review_title: Great Professional Development and Benefits, Pay at least 20% lower
pros:
great benefits (10% of salary toward 401k by CU
have a training budget, so you can develop yourself
having a planning cycle
get time between Christmas and new years off
work / life balance is fantastic
cons:
pay is lower than other schools by anywhere from 20-30% - not just peer schools, but schools with much lower goals
in order to move up within the department, you almost have to leave because there is very little movement
there is no cost of living increase - you are lucky to get 2%/year

pros: Cornell is a huge organization, so I can only speak for the Chemical Engineering department. The research base of the department is very large, covering everything from cancer treatments to solar cells. The diversity of collaborations is very valuable, but you will need to reach outside the department to find specialized people to work with.
cons: Coming from NYC, Ithaca is the smallest town I've ever lived in, and it pinches sometimes. The combination of icy winters and steep hills is not great. But these are problems with the setting, not the university per se.

pros: Access to great educational resources, practice teaching with highly skilled students in primarily discussion environments, some opportunities to practice giving lectures, credentials that can be useful for future job applications, provides higher pay than many similar programs at other graduate schools (although not much compared to jobs outside of graduate programs)
cons:
I was working with the department of Art History, so I can't speak directly to any other departments (although I heard similar stories from graduate student teachers in several other departments).  However, there are numerous cons I have encountered during my time teaching with Cornell; I will mention a few of the most significant here.  

To begin with, for most teaching positions, there is neither any training nor any supervision (and evaluation from others who already have teaching experience).  As a result, graduate instructors have to figure out how to teach on their own without any feedback outside of the students' own evaluations at the end of each semester.  This leads to unnecessary challenges for both the TA instructors and the students, and hinders both teaching abilities and opportunities for professional development.

Another significant flaw is that graduate TA instructors are told that their TA work should only take at most 15 hours a week, and therefore their work as students is apportioned accordingly to fill the rest of their schedule (3-5 classes) and they are paid at a comparable part-time rate.  However, the actual responsibilities required for the job tend to take significantly more time than that, sometimes reaching 50 hours a week, while graduate instructors' responsibilities for the courses they're taking can often require a similarly high number of hours.  As a result, most TA's struggle to actually fulfill both their teaching and own coursework responsibilities.  As a result, both undergrad students and graduate teachers again suffer from the stressful and ineffective structure for organizing teaching responsibilities.

As this job is intentionally deeply integrated into the learning process for graduate students at Cornell, it would seem much more appropriate if it were structured so as to actually allow the graduate students to learn how to teach well AND to not totally overwhelm their ability to both teach and do their coursework.

And that's before getting into the unhealthy and unprofessional politics of the department.  These politics severely affect graduate students' work as both students and teachers, and are a big part of the job...

review_title: Good benefits, not interested in learning from best practices.
pros: Good health and retirement benefits, very pretty campus, students are top notch. Safe location.
cons: Too many long service leaders not interested in working smarter, just harder.  HR function very outdated and not much help.  I was told by a top leader that ambitious staff either leave or get pushed aside.  That was true.

review_title: great benefits if you can work within a bureaucracy
pros: The employee benefits are wonderful, particularly medical and 401K. My particular supervisor was wonderful. I had to take medical leave and I could not have asked for a better boss during that time. She was great at giving performance reviews; no matter what your performance, you always left her office feeling great. She has retired since then.
cons: Like all big organizations, it's a bureaucracy, so there's red tape and things move slowly.

pros: Cornell provides great benefits, such as employee ongoing education and various other programs to further develop your career. Plus working at an educational institution you have some great resources to pull from.
cons: The only thing that I would say is a con is the slow transition for departments to use new and improved business practices. Some people find it hard to change from their old ways.

pros:
Everything at Cornell depends on the professors. Classes can be good or bad, interesting or boring, easy or hard, organized or disorganized, fair or completely random grades, depending on the professor and how the manage the TAs. 

As a TA, I saw differences in grading policies with different professors, and fortunately, they do listen to what the TAs think about it.
cons: Some classes are much too hard. For instance, a Discrete Structures class started teaching extensive amounts of Group Theory, far too high level for computer science majors, even TAs for the class.

review_title: Interesting. Excellent place to learn both the good and bad of the work environment.
pros: Good benefits on health, education, and flexible work schedule. One is able to advance skills and expertise from all the training available. Good health, dental and eye insurance coverage.
cons: Social isolation in Ithaca - can be lonely. Transient environment so relationships and community bonds can be short-lived. Poor leadership at the job. Not sure about the decision models. Lots of bureaucracy - delays work. Favoritism - works really well if you have connections and higher-ups invested in you.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros:
good community, The work is very interesting and challenging cases
can be mini problemsolving
exercises and it's enormously fulfilling to file a report and finish up a project. Smart
people from top colleges are good to brainstorm with. People are generally
hardworking and do not slack off, so there is a lot of cooperation and a collaborative
work style.
cons:
As anywhere, if there is something boring, the most junior analyst got it. But it's
educational, and the managers generally try very hard to take analyst development
into consideration, but sometimes there are things that the team just have to wade
through.

pros: It was fairly easy to get a job with the catering department as a staff member. They let you adjust your schedule so that you can work multiple jobs and pick what days you want off.
cons: The hours for catering are awful there were many times I would be done at 1-2am and have to drive home. The expected error less work in a super high-stress, fast paced environment.

job_title: Assistant Director of Communiations in Ithaca, NY
pros: Excellent benefits, beautiful campus, fun town, brilliant students, diversity in race and intellectual pursuits, good professors, some office space is lovely, some is sub-par, surrounded by lovely countryside.
cons: Expensive housing if you live nearby, little room for advancement, far from everything except a good cup of coffee, growth opportunities are self made by the employee, there is no mechanism for upward movement.

review_title: Great place to do a PhD.  The compensation is comfortable for living in Ithaca.  Great working environment
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros:
-everyone is willing to collaborate and help each other better their research
-lots of opportunities to apply for grants and fellowship for extra money
-fun events and activities that include graduate students
-opportunity to network with important people in various fields
cons:
-this town is an ice hole in NY state
-difficult to mingle with the locals
-the bus system is abysmal
-if you have to drive for more than 10 minutes to a place, you know you're in the woods

review_title: Lots of resources for you to learn. Yet the you can have lots of work. Advisor matters!
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros: Some really smart professors and students. You can get connections to the outside too. Sometimes projects can have good impact if you get the chance and work hard.
cons: It depends really on the professor you are working with. If s/he does not have an idea or good projects, it really is not fun and a waste of time.

pros: The staff at CU are so friendly and they are patient with teaching you the systems used daily like PeopleSoft. Everyone works in a similar time frame here so you know you'll be pretty much in by 8:00 AM and out by 4:30 PM.
cons: Since the school is well-known and the town is small, there's not a real drive in some of the staff to go above and beyond since there's strong job security here. That's really not a problem unless you're someone who wants to move up quickly.

pros:
The professors you work with are very hardworking and very accomplished
Ithaca is a very nice city to live in during graduate school
Because Cornell is a big school, it has many amenities that make life easier for a graduate student
cons:
You have to work a lot as a graduate student, so if you do not enjoy working, you should not come here :)
You will also not be payed a lot, but that's also part of being a graduate student.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Ithaca, NY
pros:
Ithaca is beautiful in the summer and graduate students generally get treated well. There are many motivated faculty and great research facilities.

Ithaca also has tons of restaurants, theaters and festivals.
cons: It is inbred. Ithaca is basically Cornell and there are only academics: students and faculty. There is little industry in Ithaca, so if you are interested in business or something other than Cornell it can be pretty isolated.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros: There is a love hate relation with working at Cornell.  The love parts are the smart dedicated researchers and labs.  For some people the scenery, affordable homes, and family friendly environment are pluses.
cons: The hate part is the isolation.  It affects the dating scene, the promptness with which people graduate, and the momentum with which people get things done.  It also leads to a peculiar brand of politics among the faculty.

job_title: Mac Team Consultant in Ithaca, NY
pros: Working as a consultant is a great opportunity to learn about the various technologies used at Cornell and to help others. Hours are flexible, and the other staff members are generally willing to share their knowledge.
cons: The work can be slow at times, and it can become a bit repetitive and tedious. However, new technologies are introduced frequently enough to mitigate this.

review_title: Rigorous academic environment, but highly grounded in the real world/ job market.
pros: Great career development though job fairs, career counseling and on-campus recruitment; ability to pursue any interests (academic or non-academic) due to a plethora of elective options and extracurricular clubs; and a great campus, which is fantastic for anyone who wants a "traditional" college experience.
cons:
Awful weather - bipolar most of the time
Stress-inducing environment - in some colleges you can be taking exams almost every week on top of the regular work-load (which is substantial)
Very expensive - averaging around $60,000 pa

pros:
Flexible course instructor allowed me to take an active role in teaching process
Teaching experience has been valuable in finding other employment opportunities
Compensation for effort is better than average
cons:
It is a lot of work to do while simultaneously fulfilling master's degree requirements
Variance in the responsibilities of TA positions in throughout departments within this university, as well as many others, makes it easy for potential employers to undervalue my particular experience

review_title: Excellent university in a small town
job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Ithaca, NY
pros: The people are great, it's an intensely stimulating atmosphere, and there's a ton of beautiful nature nearby. My department (mathematics) in particular is very friendly, with a lot of incredible, computational and theoretical work going on.
cons: Sometimes it's annoying that Cornell University is a long ways away from any major city center. If you love night life, there's not a lot going on in Ithaca.

pros: Lots of collaboration, very open atmosphere, and excellent faculty who are extremely innovative and foster creativity. The facilities available are first-class, there are classes in almost any area you are interested in, and all the staff are friendly and eager and motivated to help your research.The stipend for graduate students is very high, and leads to a very comfortable lifestyle.
cons: It's a little isolated, which can mean that it can get very boring in Ithaca, especially in the winter. It helps if you have family nearby.

review_title: Great University and Place to Work
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros: The research being done at Cornell is very interesting and the facilities are amazing. Ithaca is a beautiful city. The stipend given to graduate students are higher than average.
cons: Ithaca is very cold and somewhat dreary in the winter. While the graduate student stipend is nice, the cost of living in Ithaca is also high.

pros: As an undergraduate TA (a course consultant), I really enjoy helping students and working with course staff. Everyone is responsible and communicative, and I can have an impact on the CS careers of other students.
cons: There isn't much beyond minor conveniences; the only one I can think of is that figuring out rooms for labs and discussions can get tricky when classes are larger.

review_title: Progressive Science, Great People, Not free of typical academia drawbacks
pros:
-Small town feel of Ithaca
-Fantastic science, cutting edge, opportunity to be involved in interesting work
-Great benefits and wellness programs
-Employee Degree Program or Employee Classes
cons:
-Pay can be bleak, pay raises minimal 
-Parking is difficult and costly, for those who don't live close enough to walk to work (bus route is fairly useful though)
-Winters are long
-Environment can be very stressful and competitive

review_title: Experience of working as a PhD student
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros: Great research atmosphere. Professors really really care for their students. Ample freedom to explore your interests. Immense flexibility to design your own curriculum and research deadlines at your pace.
cons: Parking is a real pain. They discourage parking during working hours and parking rates are stupendously high. Commuting from Ithaca airport can be a bit inconvenient because of routine flight cancellations and delays. Weather is even though bad, the roads are kept pretty clean throughout the year. Summer constructions are really inconvenient and annoying.

job_title: Training and Orientation Coordinator in Ithaca, NY
pros: The staff with in my department are extremely supportive and push for both personal and career growth. There are also a  of learning opportunities and professional development opportunities available to you. The management aslo appears to really care about you and work balance life.
cons: Cost of living in Ithaca is horrendously high, so you sort of have to live farther away in order to afford anything  truly livable.

review_title: Best employer in my 40+ years of professional job experience.
pros: Benefits were great. Always given opportunities for growth and advancement and participation in University committees. Upper management were willing to serve as mentors and guide newer hires in practices, protocols and policies. Encouraged self improvement in and outside of professional areas with classes, seminars, symposium, etc.
cons: I did not have any negative experiences.

review_title: Undergrad studying Information Science in Engineering
pros: The program is very comprehensive and definitely keeps you busy. There are a lot of opportunities on campus as this is a very famous university.
cons: The environment is extremely high strung. Everyone feels like they need to be the best at whatever they do and are willing to do anything to get there. The Engineering curriculum is not very flexible in the classes you can take, and there is almost no time to take classes for fun if you came without AP credit.

review_title: Perfectly normal summer job at Alumni Affairs
job_title: Student Worker In Alumni Affairs in Ithaca, NY
pros: Friendly coworkers, direct deposit paycheck, office in close proximity to campus, my boss was both helpful in teaching me skills and showing me how to do things but also was very comfortable in putting trust in me and letting me work through things at my own pace/in my own way
cons: Work was relatively boring, there seemed very little opportunity for upward mobility unless you were dedicated to making this your full-time job-- which is discouraging for any students who take the job

review_title: I was a student employee working in IT (at the ATC).
job_title: Student Technology Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros:
Everyone was very friendly and professional.
Occasionally I could do homework while waiting for projects.
Lenient dress code.
Appreciation for our work from faculty and coworkers.
Very convenient location and flexible hours.
cons:
Hourly shifts, absences and lateness are taken quite seriously, not always ideal for hectic campus life.
They pay is low considering our skillset.

review_title: The work is immensely rewarding. The work environment is extremely unwelcoming.
pros: Cornell located on a campus that stands out for its physical beauty, wonderful libraries, and full-time faculty positions. There's a strong commitment to academic freedom, and faculty voice among the faculty in Arts and Sciences, and in individual departments across the rest of the University.
cons: Status, salary, voting rights, and time-off dramatically differ for full-time non-tenure and tenure track faculty even in cases where education, experience, qualifications, experience,  and abilities are the same or greater.

pros: Decent pay, but overall fantastic leadership and a very supportive, kind community. I love it here. The community is intelligent and the surroundings are beautiful
cons: There's a large bureaucracy above you at all times, and trying to change or innovate tends to be met with a fair amount of resistance.

review_title: Ivy in the countryside with very good benefits and top  greencard sponsorship
pros: Great team of top scientits in veterinary , animal science, and biology. Other majors are also extremely strong though not my own fields. The very beautiful campus, top.benwfit to staff: children tuition benefits, nice insurance, pension match  to 6%. The high school.gets about 40 students into Cornell each year. Rather low housing cost.
cons: A bit isolated from major cities. Depending on if you prefer urban life. 5 hours drive to New York City.

pros: This is a great on campus job for students looking for an evening job. Highest starting salary on campus and nice incentives
cons: The number of refusals and negative interactions with alums can be draining for some callers. For those uncomfortable with asking fro money, this would be an awkward conversation

pros: Cornell has excellent benefits for postdocs, outstanding research, and an on-campus synchrotron. Also, the food in Ithaca is excellent, and Cayuga lake is great in the summer!
cons: Ithaca's a small town with no freeway access. It has a lot going on for its size, but it's not a city. Plus, one does have to be able to deal with winter.

pros: Depending on where you are employed within Cornell it can be a great experience, meeting and working with diverse individuals from around the world.
cons: No respect for time served, some departments have a high school quality to them. To many friendships between supervisors and subordinates that create segregation and unbalanced treatment to all employees.

pros: There are a few bright minds there
cons:
A lot of politics, some PI's are less competent than some undergraduates. PI's who don't know some of the basic properties of RNA or DNA, don't know what is going on in their lab, and don't know details of their own publications.

Deals are made between PI's to cover each other's backs and get promotions. Dean's making illogical decisions about the program in general. Over spending on empty buildings and then cutting back on resources.

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Ithaca, NY
pros: Hours are flexible, especially if you are a full-time student, which a majority of workers are in my department. The school, in general, is run by very adept managers including the current director of the Cornell Store--who has turned the store around 180 degrees for the better!
cons: More opportunities to climb the management ladder of my department

review_title: Great training for PhD, but hated the winter and isolation.
pros: Great campus, smart people, a lot of research flexibility and ways to collaborate. The stipends are generous. As with any PhD program selecting the right mentor/laboratory is key.
cons: The winter is awful. Expect tons of snow and very cold temperatures for a solid 5+ months per year. It can be very depressing. Ithaca is extremely small and isolated. Getting in and out is not trivial and especially difficult in the wintertime. Parking on campus is very expensive.

pros: Great benefits working at Cornell. The rest of the experience is up to your specific supervisor which in my case was great but I had a very unique situation.
cons: Bureaucracy and department administration at Cornell can be very difficult and slow. In my case it took about five months to approve my hire, apparently because of internal department politics.

job_title: Research Aide IV in Ithaca, NY
pros: Wonderful working environment with many tools to balance work/life. Flex schedules and remote work agreements are supported and encouraged. Continuing education and life long learning are really a part of the culture, and management is very supportive.
cons: Parking can be atrocious and expensive. Depending on your unit and role, there may be limited opportunities for advancement due to job specialization. Reviews have become more about the yearly process itself rather than an improvement tool, and the benefits of timely feedback are sometimes lost.

review_title: Job itself rewarding, coworkers borderline abusive
pros:
raise cute foals
physically active
no need to dress nicely for work
around (mostly healthy) animals all day
supervisor MADE us take breaks
cons:
certain longtime employees constantly verbally abusive, management does nothing about it
required to complete online training on various methods of euthanasia
barns lack temperature control
constantly cleaning up mistakes made by students from the vet school

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros: It really depends on your advisor and field. Some advisors are really laid-back and just let their students graduate in 5 years. But generally expect long working hours and no work life balance.
cons: It really depends on your advisor and field. But generally expect long working hours and no work life balance. Everything here at Ithaca is expensive. Just to give you an idea, the food is more expensive than NYC and rent is about two-thirds to half of the rent in NYC.

review_title: Satisfied with the Cornell Community, Administration could do more for grad students
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros: Great please to spend several years of your life. Access to great facilities, libraries. Fun town, campus.
cons: Like many universities, Cornell needs to figure out what to do with its PhD. It can't keep training them for lives with academia. Better career development is necessary. More resources to facilitate efficient and rapid completion of dissertation and degree requirements.

review_title: Generally good, sometimes lots more time and work than desired
pros: Very flexible hours in general, fun, not required to do too much if classes take lots of time, food given during grading sessions
cons: Sometimes lots more work than desired, requires late night grading sessions that can run for several hours, often dragged into staying in office hours over time without pay

pros:
Great student staff

Great summer weather 

Great University 

Great social scene if you find the right people. 

Historic buildings. 
Great education. Location ok.
cons:
Weather is very bad. I do not recommend studying let alone being an RA at this place. Benefits are horrible compared to other schools, rooms are the worst. 

Cornell is very skimpy and will try to milk any money from you. Training is horrendous 

Policies are the absolute worst of the worst.

review_title: Lovely campus, so many opportunities available for education, travel, entertainment, and fitness.
pros: Great benefits including educational and wellness opportunities. Employee discounts all over town including travel, merchandise, and even cell phone service.
cons: Low salaries, long hours making it difficult or impossible to take advantage of opportunities, very poor raises, terrible management and HR department. Management is too top heavy, and there is less and less staff to do work due to budget cuts. Little or No opportunity for advancement once you are pigeon-holed.

pros: Cornell provides the opporutnity to engage and support efforts of future leaders (students) and current recognized leaders (academic and non-academic). There is also a sense of excitement being on a campus around students even if your job doesn't directly work with students.
cons:
Getting connected in the community however Cornell is trying to help address this moving forward.
Winter can feel long some years however if you like seasons, Ithaca has great seasons and tends not to have earthquakes, tornadoes or hurricanes!

pros: Mindful of student obligations. Professors and other faculty are fantastic resources. Flexible schedule. Once you are in, it is fairly simple to move across positions in different classes and get involved in research.
cons: Sometimes there is a bit of lack of organization and communication regarding specific obligations. Although you are part of a professor's staff, you are managed by a student, who may not always provide the most helpful guidelines from the get go.

pros: Retirement contribution good, healthcare excellent, amazing opportunities for education (I got my MA while working -- for free! and took other classes on the side), flexibility, work-life balance, coworkers/general community full of intellectuals.  Obviously it depends on what job you are working for a lot of these things, but I was a research aide (and alumnus).  Ithaca is a very reasonably priced place to live.
cons: It's removed from most cities (so con for some, pro for others).

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros: A lot of smart and talented people, collaborative environment, professors (at least in my department) generally cared about the well-being of their students, interesting research. Summers weren't bad, small town charm.
cons: Cold and long winters, stormy, muggy in the summer. Work load could get tough depending on your adviser. Not much to do in terms of entertainment like bars, clubs, museums, cultural venues etc. unless you get creative or just enjoy chilling out in the woods. Student body seemed homogeneous. Entitled undergrads.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros: Good benefits if you're on a locked-in stipend plan. Basic medical insurance is fully covered, and the stipend is enough to live well in Ithaca
cons: Dental and eye coverage requires outside payment, and it's tough for grad students who are parents. Ithaca is cold and snowy, but Cornell never seems to close.

pros: Excellent place to work, truly feel appreciated and respected for current job performance and for the wealth of experience I brought to the university.  Diversity and inclusion are high priorities. And it is wonderful to be in an environment dedicated to transforming the students' lives and the lives of people around the world through research and activism.
cons: Ithaca is a small town, need to take that into consideration, but otherwise this is truly a wonderful place to live and work.

pros: I work with a great team and we do great work for our youth!!!  Being in the City we reach a large group in NYC.
cons: The University does not provide the same benefits for employees located in NYC,  limited gym benefits in NYC, since not on campus,  child care and  education accessibility.

review_title: Tough location, but there are some benefits; great place to live if you love small, liberal college towns.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros: Pay is good, Cornell staff in general are very friendly, Cornell and Ithaca in general are beautiful.
cons: Hours worked much higher than expected, little mentoring from faculty (though that is almost certainly department-specific), food on campus is too expensive for graduate students, Ithaca is far from...everything

pros: Fantastic benefits, even for part-time employees. Competitive pay for the area. Abundant training opportunities.
cons:
Some departments are great to work for while others can be frustrating.
You can't negotiate a raise within your current position so must change jobs frequently to grow your salary.

pros: Cornell University is overall a great place to work, the work is interesting and there are so many seminars available on campus to attend, if time permits, both academic and work-life balance seminars.  The campus is kept clean and repaired.  I find most of the other employees very nice and helpful
cons: The snow in Ithaca can be problematic sometimes and the campus should close more often when the roads and the weather are bad.

pros: If the small town environment is a fit - a great place to minimize distractions and focus - Ithaca is an ideal place to post doc.  Opportunities to collaborate with the Weill campus in NYC abound. There are plenty of other post docs and students at this big research campus in a small town.
cons: Travel is difficult, as the airport is small and Ithaca is a bit out of the way - the flip side to the above.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Ithaca, NY
pros:
People working together to move the world forward
Caring and collaborative colleagues
Excellent development programs for faculty and staff
Progressively develop people 
Excellent benefits and higher education benefits
Beautiful location and campus
Close to lakes, ski resorts, Adironack and Allegany mountains
A few hour bus ride to downtown Manhatten - enjoy nature while connecting to a bustling metropolis
cons: Snow a few days a year, but then one can choose to flex from home

pros: You are always surrounded by very smart people. This can encourage to do your best on assigned projects. Wide ranges of networking opportunities. Library with full-access to online journals and publications. It is definitely a very diverse community.
cons: Definitely, the extreme winters in Ithaca can play an important role on a decision to leave but it is enormously compensated with the ridiculous chances to meet interesting people on classes and meetings. On campus fitness centers need to expanded.

review_title: A great place to be for nanotech
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros: Excellent facilities and facility management, smart co-workers of diverse backgrounds, collaboration-friendly atmosphere, good benefits package, higher salary than other grad students, nice natural surroundings/ waterfalls, cool downtown commons area in ithaca
cons: Cold, occasionally nasty weather but not as snowy as people think, difficult to access big cities (not counting Binghamton and Syracuse (~1hr away),

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Geneva, NY
pros:
The grad student stipend is very high compared to other schools I looked at.
Lots of opportunities to explore anything you are interested in through research, classes, and travel.
cons:
No guidance at all as an off main campus grad student. Had no idea what my benefits were for more than a year.
Being a Geneva based grad student means years of frustration at commuting no matter where you choose to live. You either commute for classes or for research.

job_title: Outdoor Education Instructor in Ithaca, NY
pros: Great people. Very fun outdoor trips with well trained staff. Administration is flexible, cares about you, and the overall culture of the work place is hard to beat.
cons: Did not pay too well after a full semester of work even though myself and fellow employees deserved more. Weather during late winter is depressing.

pros: I worked with some great, really intelligent, people across several units in my time at Cornell, faculty, staff and grad students The benefits are great and they are one employer that really stands behind their professional development promises. Work life balance is taken seriously too.
cons: As great as the benefits were, it was surprising how few paid holidays staff were offered. Also, the university is trying to improve but still has few people of color employed in professional positions.

pros: Incredible work / life balance.  Very competitive pay in comparison to peer institutions.  Low cost of living.  Ithaca in the summer is nice.
cons: Ithaca in the winter is not nice.  Very remote.  Bureaucracy has become very bad over the last five years.  Parking sucks.

review_title: Food service: great people to work with
job_title: Food Service Worker in Ithaca, NY
pros: Friendly workers both at my levels and above, simple relationships are easy to form, flexible hours. Certain dining halls have better food than others, this is a plus for food service workers because you get free food (all you can eat) during your shift.
cons: After-work life is not as exciting, of course this is not really Cornell's fault, but probably should be something to think about if you prefer a city life.

review_title: Fantastic way to get a little extra spending money. The best job I will EVERY have.
pros: I was able to study for school while getting resume-quality experience.
cons: I have nothing bad to say about the organization. Although there may be room to make the organization more efficient, customer service could suffer as a result. Students expect to have access to the library and any reorganization could put that into jeopardy.

review_title: Cornell University is a wonderful institution to work for. They treat their employees wonderfully.
job_title: Office and Events Coordinator in New York, NY
pros:
Wonderful health and dental benefits. 
Professional development is a key focus of the University. 
Diversity and inclusion are highly promoted within the departments. 
Great sense of community.
cons:
Some individuals are harder to work with than most. 
Some managers are unable to adapt to the changing environment emotionally.

pros: Beautiful campus, lots of events going on.  The Employee Degree Program is a great perk.
cons: Hard to implement change, not much listening (both up/down and across).  Because there isn't that much turnover, there is a fair amount of "we've always done it this way" culture.

pros: Minimal paperwork. They really focus on your work as a PE teacher. I taught ballroom dance classes for seven semesters. It was a blast.
cons: Sometimes the payroll information is complicated. The business and paycheck office actually missed one of my payments because my information had been delayed.

job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros: Students are very eager to learn and come to office hours with insightful questions. Recitations are always an active back and forth between me and my students.
cons: One of the negatives is large class sizes. This can make it difficult to balance one on one sessions with students with helping everyone on the whole.

pros: Benefits hours and coworkers are all quite stellar.  This is easily the best workplace I've been apart of.  Highly recommended as an employer
cons: Hard to fill this section.  The pay is on the lower side. For the position and work load.  However it is remedied by the full benefits

review_title: Great learning experience, but difficult management
job_title: Project Specialist for Outreach and Communication in Ithaca, NY
pros: Great connection to Cornell University and the opportunity to work with faculty to improve the educational strategies for the entire campus. Great location on campus.
cons: Salary was terrible, no benefits available. There is nowhere in the building to have lunch with coworkers. Everyone just eats in their cubicles. Leadership was lacking and quite erratic. The organization strategies are behind closed doors and there is very little long term planning.

review_title: Great benefits- if you get to use them
job_title: Administrative Assistant IV in Ithaca, NY
pros: There seems to be a core that wants to make this a good place to work
cons: There are too many bad managers, and not enough people willing to do anything about it.  There really isn't anything else in the area, so this is the number one employer, which really gets people stuck in some horrible situations.

review_title: Cornell is an excellent organization to work for.
pros: Flexibility, ability to learn new skills, living the "academic life," commitment to diversity, great perks, great team environment, tight-knit community, great place for working families.
cons: Limited opportunity for growth, less opportunities for managing people (which would lead to personal growth), funding is sometimes a problem for certain offices to stay staffed.

review_title: Very strong institution for natural sciences
pros: Many laboratories in the field of biochemistry, biology, biophysics, genetics. Strong computer center. Professors from physics and Chemistry and Chemical Biology department have a lot of grants. Students are known to be hard-working students. Big library with electronic subscription to all science journals. Big nano-center with numerous modern fabrication machinery. Relatively cheap apartments if not in close proximity to University. Easy to park car.
cons: Strong competition for the job position.

pros: I worked at one of the library branches as a student employee.  The manager was very professional, and I got to interact with professors and students on a direct basis - fulfilling their requests, conversing with them, etc.  It was good for money and also good for professional connections.
cons: No advancement opportunity at the position, but I think if I wanted to I could've continued working elsewhere at CU.

job_title: Graduate Research/Teaching Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros: Ithaca is a cute mini city and Cornell is really a nice place to work. They pay grad students well. Personally, I find the work-life balance great and I love it there. Hard working but not high stress. Good culture
cons: It is hard for spouses to find jobs here though, there is not a lot of work in Ithaca unless you are in a really high-demand career like programming or IT.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros:
I was in ECE department so my review is only for this department.
-Very decent stipend compared to other schools.
-Interdisciplinary research opportunities.
-Scenic campus, a lot of water falls and physical education classes to learn interesting sports.
-fun college town
-Department pays for health insurance - very few schools do that these days.
cons:
Few people complain about the weather but there are others who love Ithaca because of its weather.
Because of its location, sometimes it gets depressing

job_title: PhD Research Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros: very good! our Cs facilities were great and it was a great place to learn to do good research. good funding for work and fun.
cons: of course being in Ithaca can be challenging due to the harsh winters. but you figurei to ut, you deal.

pros: It is a famous academic institution with great faculty members. We have a great deal of resources available to do research and job search.
cons: The study here is quite stressful. Course work is very intense. And I also need to do research or TA duties aside that.

review_title: Teaching assistantship was fun but took up too much time
pros: It was a lot of fun to interact with intelligent and inquisitive students. Always enjoyed the challenge of presenting new ideas and concepts to students.
cons: Prep work, grading, meetings take up a lot of time  - perhaps more hires will make this process easier. Also, it would help to get more specialized graders so that teaching assistants can concentrate on best presenting the material.

review_title: Staff member of the College of Agriculture and Life Sciences
pros: Inspiring mission and research; laid-back work environment; scenic and progressive community - great place for families
cons: University organization is confusing and bureaucracy can be frustrating; location is a bit isolated for city lovers; cost of living higher than it should be, with disappointing medical options (be prepared to go an hour to Syracuse, Binghamton or Elmira for any specialist care, or even a pediatric dentist.

review_title: [Dept. of CompSci] Excellent to TA in
job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros: Excellent hourly wage for an undergrad, generally a great work/life balance as you're able to TA and review the material on the side of your own coursework.
cons: Can't think of many, it's highly dependent on the professor(s) you work for, some are better than others when it comes to course staff.

job_title: IT Support Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros: Benefits, People, Atmosphere, Job responsibility’s, culture, office, time off (holidays, sick, vacay, etc).
cons: Commute (not their fault obviously), bus ride from car to office

job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros: Being a TA at Cornell is a lot of fun since you get to help students learn material better, and it's genuinely interesting to get to know how people conceptualize course material differently than you do. It's also a good way to make connections within the computer science major.
cons: The pay isn't great, but there lots of non-monetary benefits to being a TA, so this isn't that big an issue.

pros: It is a top notch university with a small town feel. The name goes along way on your resume when applying for new jobs.
cons: The city is very small, and a lot of residents regret having snobby Ivy league students in their town. Winters are a pain.

job_title: Operations Specialist in New York, NY
pros:
-A lot of opportunities to move up within the University
-Lots of training/learning opportunities
-Great educational benefits
cons:
-Subject to the same bureaucracy that is found in most educational institutions
-HR's job descriptions aren't always representative of what you're job will actually be, need to upgrade their career track designs

pros: Great time to do homework and the supervisors are very friendly and relaxed. You basically get paid to moderate and ask questions, doing homework in your free time.
cons: Low paying, but it is justified. The training is sometimes confusing because everything is constantly changing. Lots of updates and sometimes people are extremely messy.

review_title: depends on who you work for
pros: established setup, good colleagues, good benefits though pay is very low. lots of things to do including gyms, concerts, student clubs
cons: weather, weather, weather, broken equipment in certain shared user labs, absent or long distance bosses make it very difficult to perform or be judged fairly.

pros: Its on campus, and has a very flexible work schedule. they understand busy times (prelim season, lot of hw, etc...)
cons: Low pay for students, raises are basically non-existent for students, very little room for growth for students, but these are all expected for student jobs.

job_title: Graduate Research/Teaching Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros: Meaningful interactions with important faculty.  Ability to subsidize cost of education.  Interaction with bright undergraduate students. Hours are generally good unless you work for a slave driver.
cons: You can live on the stipend, but it is difficult to really live.  If you work for a faculty member who is not kind, you do not have any way to complain or resolve problems without damaging your career prospects.

pros: Laid back environment. Most people are very nice and easy to get along with. My boss is very relaxed and understanding and will do his best to take as much stress away from us as he can. Good benefits.
cons: Lack of diversity. I work in a science lab and most of my coworkers are old white men. Pay is decent enough, but apartments in Ithaca are very expensive.

pros: From my experience, the community of TA's is very friendly and a fun work environment. If you like helping students understand the material and are generally personable, TAing will most likely be an overall positive experience.
cons: Can be unorganized at times. In addition, everyone puts in different amounts of time, which may lead to frustration if you end up feeling like you are working harder than other people.

review_title: Great place to work, but expect high variation depending on department
pros: Access to resources was a plus. As long as I had a reason and could make a case for needing resources (teaching support, materials, research aids, etc.) I could usually get anything I needed to help me succeed.
cons: At times politics arise. Particularly in Ithaca where it is a small community filled with very accomplished people who often have large egos.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros: They have an excellent system of benefits. Furthermore, the some research assistant positions allow you to accumulate credits (for Grad School).
cons: Very difficult work culture to penetrate and become assimilated into, as all the senior researchers and scientists regard junior assistants with an almost snobby disdain.

pros: The University has several options to work within and they are helpful in making contacts. Working in an academic setting turned out to be the same as in corporate.
cons: The deadlines can sometimes be extremely narrow and fitting everything in that time frame can compromise on your health in the long run.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Ithaca, NY
pros: The environment is very collaborative and supports communication between researchers and laboratories. This fosters both innovation and efficiency in research.
cons: Central New York in general is extremely cold during the winters, where frequent snow and the lack of sunshine leads to a rather poor quality of life. Additionally, Cornell University is located in an area with little choice in types of food cuisines.

pros: The cornell university will give you all the resources you need to complete your own research, not to mention the prestege that comes with it
cons: Although It is an ivy league school, the pay is not what you would expect for your ability or experience.

job_title: IT Support Technician in Ithaca, NY
pros: nice city, nice people, good place to retire, weathers nice, good variety of food and local restaurant. there are college girls.
cons: no place to advance. people dont care about excellence, just care about getting the work done. No quality control and falseness

pros:
Great employee support, training, and low-cost or free education.  One of the best employers I've had.
Not going out of business any time soon.
cons: Budget cuts hurt - especially in environments used to low accountability.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros: My department was very caring and advocated for its graduate students and listened when they brought complaints.
cons: there was very little consequences at the university level for professors who mistreated their graduate students (be it sexual harassment or lack of mentorship, or psychological abuse)

review_title: Cornell is a great place to work!
job_title: IT Support Services Manager in Ithaca, NY
pros: There are so many opportunities for growth, but you have to put in the work! Very generous vacation and HAP time. There is a tremendous focus on wellbeing. A healthy work life balance is also achievable for those that set boundaries.
cons: The only downsides are finding affordable housing in Ithaca, and the horrible traffic patterns of downtown Ithaca.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros: Best climate. Some complain, but whether is great, the cold is enjoyable (go skiing or snow shoing)
cons: grad school is not job oriented. took me 3 years to find a suitable job. advisor couldn't care less, companies always want to know if you know the skills to succeed, but don't want understand they can be picked up on the job.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros: Workload is generally not too demanding when considered alongside the range of other duties that graduate students have, but it can be quite variable over the term of a semester.
cons: At times, particularly mid- and late-semester, workloads for courses being taught can increase markedly. This can be problematic when one is simultaneously taking graduate courses, which tend to vary in workload in a similar fashion.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros: The university has a broad range of competencies.  Professors and students form a vibrant intellectual community which spills over into Ithaca life.
cons: The community (including the city of Ithaca) is relatively small.  The opportunities to travel to a larger cultural center are geographically limited.

review_title: Cornell University is a good place for research work
pros: Lots of top professors, scientists, and researchers to collaborate with. The university has excellent atmosphere to discuss scientific questions. It also provides plenty of resources for various studies.
cons: The campus locates in a small and relatively isolated town. The internet speed is much slower than most universities. The weather is too cold if you are from some warm places.

pros: Experiences are significantly different depending on your manager. I was lucky to be on a great staff with a good supervisor. Increase benefits based on experience
cons:
Training lacking. 
Poor weather
No difference in compensation among the position even though some communities do more work than others

pros: Great scientific facilities. Great staff support. Great minds in general at all level of the organization.  Great benefits as far as postdoc goes (Staff -- not student -- benefits)
cons: Two body employment problems frequent in such isolated area. Gotta enjoy winter. Professors are typically very driven/competitive and hence might not be prone to encourage work life balance (although this is really a case by case situation)

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Ithaca, NY
pros: If you're a student there are ample opportunities to find fairly well paying jobs with an incredible amount of flexibility.
cons: Sometimes difficult to manage school work with actual employment. More of an issue for students from low income households though.

pros:
1. Cornell University has Great Benefits system and pension
2. They care a lot about health and workplace issue
3. The pay is very decent
4. Free Bus Ride in Tompkins County
5. Very supportive of career development 
6. Coworkers are very professional and nice
cons: Office politics are still existing. Some departments might have to struggle. The snow in Ithaca can be bad in the winter.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Ithaca, NY
pros: Flexible scheduling. Good benefits. Great environment. The overall nature of Cornell University is a leading academic institution that is a challenging and beneficial place to work.
cons: Select aspects of technology seem to lag behind at the Ithaca campus. As an academic institution, can also be highly bureaucratic.

pros:
A commitment to inclusiveness
Opportunities for professional development
Good benefits
cons:
Decentralized environment - work experience can be vastly different in the same arena of work
Compensation is marginally competitive
If relocating - Ithaca, NY is a great town but only 150 days of sun

pros: Very good research school. very demanding environment.  good OR department, there are several interesting classes, many good speakers visit school.
cons: Small city, winters are pretty cold, and cloudy. Classes are very demanding. People work a lot which raises the bar.

review_title: Supportive Community, Difficult to do cross-field research
job_title: Graduate Student/Teaching Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros: Generous in allowing me 4 years of leave time, pay for a physics grad student much higher than most universities, has community activities like the winter party where the first years put on skits.
cons: Professors are very distant in classroom setting, I wanted to do a research project that was in another field with a physics professor but couldn't.

pros: Exposure to a variety of projects allows for personal growth, a great learning environment allows for truly revolutionary therapies and experiments. My boss was a polite and amiable individual who always had something exciting for me to help with.
cons: Everyone is always incredibly busy with clinical work, making it difficult to get things done. The pay was ok.
